title: Old Testament and Related Studies        (The Collected Works of Hugh Nibley, Volume 01)
author: Nibley, Hugh
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Nibley is one of my favorite authors. I have a lot more to write about the specifics of this volume's treasures, but seriously, I have another Nibley Nibley is one of my favorite authors. I have a lot more to write about the specifics of this volume's treasures, but seriously, I have another Nibley volume that I have to finish reading first. My friens Zina, Nibley's youngest daughter, recounted how her father was a prolific reader known for sitting in the library with a stack of books guarded by one arm while he plowed through volume after volume, taking notes on whatever interested him along the way. He was a true Christian apologist who engaged the world through his beloved gospel lens. A personal aside, Nibley's curmudgeonly humor, brilliance, and associative mind are reason enough to love spending time with him, but I feel compelled to explain why I have set a goal to read all of his collected works in honor of my Finnish father, Valto Antero Tolvanen. I grew up during the 1960s through the 1980s with my scholarly father reading Nibley, discussing what he discovered, and then clacking away with his lightning fast peculiar two-finger typing method on his huge Finnish-keyed olive green WWII-era typewriter, as he translated, eventually with Hugh's blessing, all of his available works at the time into Finnish. He began this task with Lehi in the Deseet to improve his own knowledge of English. Well, the Finns are known as the most literate nation in the world and Dad didn't want them to miss out on Nibley. A peculiar ability of Dad's was his uncanny way of translating what Vladimir Nobokov called the author's signature (voice), including his sense of humor and irony. They were kindred spirits. Dad and Hugh had met in the early 1970s and when Dad died in 1991, his translations of Nibley were housed at Brigham Young University with FARMS, the Fundation for Ancient Research and Mormon Studies. The binders housing these translations sat awaiting publication for several decades, until my sister and I retrieved them, after realizing that the small Finnish audience Dad was aiming to reach was't exactly high on FARMS' priority list. But, hopefully someday the manuscripts will see the light of day with technology advances to scan his typewritten pages, take them through AI copyediting and into a digital form....more

title: The Biology Of Belief: Unleashing The Power Of Consciousness, Matter And Miracles
author: Lipton, Bruce H.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is my second time reading this book. The first time in 2006, much of what Dr. Lipton wrote about was considered pseudoscience by the scientific cThis is my second time reading this book. The first time in 2006, much of what Dr. Lipton wrote about was considered pseudoscience by the scientific community. Now many of the ideas that he brought forth, including the intelligence of cells, which was also the subject of Dr. Candace Pert in "Molecules of Emotion" (she was nominated for a Nobel prize) are more mainstream. Dr. Lipton's most fascinating ideas include the importance of community throughout systems including cellular life. Recently, I read an article in the New York Times, about the discovery that plants talk to one another and actually use little clicking sounds to express danger or thirst. How little we really understand about the world we live in. Science is still in its infancy. Descarte's idea of the body as mechanical clock, for instance, still prevails. Mind, body, and spirit are still divided. Until we learn to become true scientists, and examine interconnected systems in the forest and not just a solitary spot on a tree, we are merely dabbling at the edges of the billions of galaxies that surround us. I ackowledge the strides we have made in science. Yet, I also llove intrepid explorers who continue to ask questions. Dr. Lipton is one of these. ...more

title: Lehi in the Desert, The World of the Jaredites, There Were Jaredites        (The Collected Works of Hugh Nibley, Volume 05)
author: Nibley, Hugh
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I was a teen my father began (with Hugh Nibley’s permission) to translate Nibley’s works into Finnish on his manual typewriter. He began on this When I was a teen my father began (with Hugh Nibley’s permission) to translate Nibley’s works into Finnish on his manual typewriter. He began on this labor of love with Lehi in the Desert until his death in 1992. He had by then completed a majority of the volumes and given them to BYU F.A.RM.S. Sadly, Finnish is not a priority language and nothing has been published and F.A.RM.S. is now dissolved. It took several decades for me to begin seriously reading Nibley’s books and after finishing some of the collected works, I am hooked and hope to read the majority of them. One of my favorites this far has been Temple and Cosmos. This is Volume 5 of his series. If you want to read this 3 book volume, Lehi in the Desert is my recommendation as it is very accessible and contains so many details that enrich one’s understanding of the Jewish and Egyptian cultures at the time of Lehi (600 BCE). I have read this one several times and continue to return to it with questions. The relationship between Egypt and Jerusalem is discussed as are naming conventions, habits of the “desert dwellers”, the significance of the honeybee, and much, much more. The second and third books are about the Jaredite civilization. Nibley presents unusual, yet convincing evidence as to the origins of this mysterious group that is fascinating. He hypothesizes that despite a lack of archeological artifacts, he can present his points from a bigger picture of how they fit into a pattern of many civilizations that have acted in identical ways, beginning with large scale migrations and ending with an almost overnight destruction of a people. If you are interested in a thread of thought that extends from the Central Asian steppes to warrior kings, chivalry, intrigues, assassins, final battles, and more, the World of the Jaredites may be fascinating. The final book, And There were Jaredites was not as compelling for me, but basically expanded and then summarized points from the second book within a creative conversation between imaginary scholars. Nibley is somewhat of a legend. What I love about Hugh Nibley is his wide-ranging mind. In w wry book the list of sources that he has consulted (or should I say, digested), to come up with his conclusions is staggering. And best of all, he adds in footnotes that are always worth reading. For me, he is a reader’s delight....more

title: A New Approach to Studying The Gospel of Jesus Christ
author: Rosenvall, Lynn & David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So many harmonies of the gospel are available as we study the New Testament in 2023, this is by far the best that I have discovered. It’s just scriptuSo many harmonies of the gospel are available as we study the New Testament in 2023, this is by far the best that I have discovered. It’s just scripture, which I want, rather than commentary (which has been done so many times). The book is meticulously organized. We see the birth and events leading up to the 3 year ministry of the Savior ordered chronologically as 244 events. With an abundance of white space for annotations, the volume includes the JST and Greek translation texts and offers excellent reader pointers by way of marginal footnotes indicating who is speaking, what passages are quotations and their source, scriptural references, place names, dates, and duplicate account scripture references. Helpful material is included in the appendix including several maps, the Jewish calendar, and an hourly calendar of the last week.The rational for how this was created is unique and I would say, brilliant, making it so easy to work through as a reader. Highly recommended....more

author: Doerr, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Spectacular. This novel was one that drew me inside the imagined worlds of Doerr much like a MC Escher drawing. I refused to read anything about the nSpectacular. This novel was one that drew me inside the imagined worlds of Doerr much like a MC Escher drawing. I refused to read anything about the novel before beginning and allowed myself to slip into the multiple story lines that weave their threads throughout this hauntingly compelling bricolage. This is a paean to bibliofiles and libraries, an echo of Jorge Luis Borges' the Library of Babel. It is an uplifting novel to enjoy but also one that merits discussion because of the interconnected web of ideas that it touches upon. It is why I love to read; a book crafted for times such as this.Quote: "It all leaves Anna breathless. All her life she has been led to believe that she is a child born at the end of things: the empire, the era, the reign of men on earth. But . . . beyond the horizon, other possibilities might exist, and in daydreams she takes flight across the Aegean, ships and islands and storms passing far below, the wind streaming through her spread fingers, until she alights in a bright clean palace, full of Justice and Moderation, its rooms lined with books, free to anyone who can read them. " p. 174...more

author: Anderson, Karl Ricks
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wound my way slowly through this book, written by Karl Anderson, a brother of a former colleague and well-known author, Richard Lloyd Anderson. ThisI wound my way slowly through this book, written by Karl Anderson, a brother of a former colleague and well-known author, Richard Lloyd Anderson. This is a work that took 40 years of gathering to write. Neal A. Maxwell encouraged the author to develop the manuscript to recount the Christology underpinning the story of the early Latter-day Saint experience in Kirtland, Ohio and the marvelous spiritual manifestations experienced by members of the faith. It was a heady time described at its apex as a “Day of Pentecost”, a time in the fledgling Church where the heavens opened and angels walked among saints. Filled with details and quotations that are not readily available, I was fascinated with the construction of the book, as Anderson described the Christ-centered evidences of the Savior in Kirtland. A favorite chapter was 14, on the gathering of Israel. If you enjoy gospel scholarship, this may be for you....more

title: The mountain trail and its message
author: Palmer, Albert Wentworth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 1911. Time measured on a slow arc. The Sierra Club wilderness experience hike brings a group of members together each summer to explore the vast, pris1911. Time measured on a slow arc. The Sierra Club wilderness experience hike brings a group of members together each summer to explore the vast, pristine wilderness of the Western United States. Each walker brings only camping essentials including a pair of hobnail boots to walk along winding trails, on long days that conclude with a fiddler playing hymns to weary travelers after a plain, yet nourishing dinner served by the camp cook and his assistants. It is a genteel time. Whispers of poetry dot the writing as do references to the legendary John Muir, who “never hurried. . . [and] would hail people passing by and make them get down on hands and knees if necessary to examine some tiny seedling or to see the beauty of some little bed of almost microscopic flowers.” 28Albert Wentworth Palmer records his experience during or summer in a brief, but beautiful tribute to the physical and spiritual fulfillment found in this annual event. This little book may seem old-fashioned, but it is worth reading slowly and pondering life as it was almost a century ago....more

title: Teachings of the Doctrine of Eternal Lives
author: Anonymous
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Fascinating compilation by "Anonymous" of quotations on what the title words might mean. Not for every reader as it is like following a trail of starsFascinating compilation by "Anonymous" of quotations on what the title words might mean. Not for every reader as it is like following a trail of stars into the mysteries of the universe. Who am I, Why am I here? Where am I going? The eternally asked questions with no easy answers. This is the taut, often impenetrable border between things that are perceived through faith or spiritual senses and the objective Decartesian mind. title: Deep River
author: Marlantes, Karl
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It a odd how often hIstory is an echo of the words we recount as being our story. When my father was a boy Finland’s struggles toward nationhood incluIt a odd how often hIstory is an echo of the words we recount as being our story. When my father was a boy Finland’s struggles toward nationhood included strife between whites and the reds that often tore apart families. This novel begins where some of my own family stories begin. My recently widowed grandfather was marched away at sunset as a prisoner of war in 1917 leaving behind his three young sons. My stories meld with Karl Marlantes’ family memories. Deep River is a gutsy story. A story of survival. Through two world wars, famine, loss, and sorrow, my father also survived, gained an education, and married. Then he emigrated in 1956 from Finland to Vancouver, Canada, leaving behind a comfortable career for a new life. Like the family in Deep River, my father’s first job in Canada was with a crew of immigrant Finns, working as loggers on the wild northwest coast of Vancouver Island. Father, at nearly age 50 became a topper, a most dangerous occupation, scaling to the heights of the immense coastal Douglas Fir trees to cut and release their swaying crowns to the crew below. We arrived a few months later to join him and began again. The story of Deep River is the story of immigrants. It is the story that the elders tell. It is a story that reminds us of things that should not be forgotten. It is a story of hardship, sacrifice, love, and family. It is in its emotional landscape, my story, even when the details do not match. How could I not be drawn in by this bigger than life, stark, amazing novel?...more

title: One by One
author: Bednar, David A.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I enjoy Elder Bednar’s way of delving into words and phrases in the scriptures. He is a master of finding principles to live by in the scriptures. In I enjoy Elder Bednar’s way of delving into words and phrases in the scriptures. He is a master of finding principles to live by in the scriptures. In this slender volume, he searches the scriptures to find mention of incidents where Christ notices and reaches out to the “one” while making the case that we all are individually known and loved by a kind, merciful Father and his Son. Our lives are filled with encounters and incidents, but there are no coincidences, he writes. Instead, there is divine and loving orchestration happening that we often cannot see. Elder Bednar includes stories of tender mercies that occur when people are prompted to reach out to others, to help and comfort the ”one” as we are asked to do in the second great commandment. These acts of ministering to others in turn bring us closer to emulating the character of Christlike service. My favorite part of this book was where he elaborated on the times that the phrase “one by one” is mentioned in the Book of Mormon. Somehow, I had not really noticed the repetition of this phrase before, nor it’s significance. Beautiful truths are to be found in this chapter. Sometimes a slim, simple volume contains the most powerful truths. As Elder Bednar writes: “As we consistently seek for eyes to see and ears to hear, we can discern and detect the tender mercies of the Lord in our lives—as we are blessed both to receive them and to act as instruments in the hands of the Savior to deliver them to other people.” 160...more

review: While this is not my favorite novel by Barbara Kingsolver, I thoroughly enjoyed the information surrounding Mary Street, a brilliant mind whose corresWhile this is not my favorite novel by Barbara Kingsolver, I thoroughly enjoyed the information surrounding Mary Street, a brilliant mind whose correspondence with other Victorian era botanists and scientists including Charles Darwin, was a new revelation to me. Kingsolver always does her homework and her fascination portrait of Mary Street as well as her insights into the close-minded society she inhabited was fascinating. Her work in botany and how easily we have brushed over her research reminds me of other brilliant women of her time including artist Mary Hallock Foote (in Wallace Steiner’s Angle of Repose) and Mary Anning, the British fossil hunter (in Tracy Chevalier’s Remarkable Creatures). Mary Street is only one facet of this novel, however, and it’s dual storyline is an interesting study in contrasts between two eras and two families as their daily dramas play out in the small town of Vineland, New Jersey, where Mary Treat lived at one time. My favorite quote in the book is taken from Willa Cather: “Unsheltered, I live in daylight. And like the wandering bird I rest in thee.”...more

title: The Girl in Grey
author: Lyon, Annette*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My mother fell in love with a tall, dark and handsome stranger who become my father. An enlisted man, my father was a lieutenant in the white-clad FinMy mother fell in love with a tall, dark and handsome stranger who become my father. An enlisted man, my father was a lieutenant in the white-clad Finnish army who knew their harsh winters and fought, often guerilla warfare on skis. Mother waited for him for nearly 5 years, faithfully writing letters from Helsinki to the front as the battles Finland fought with neighboring Russia, raged on in the Winter War and the Continuation War during World War II. My father finally came home, a decorated veteran, but seldom spoke about his experiences. After his death we have read his journals and pondered at the photos in his album dedicated to this time. Annette Lyon's novel, The Girl in Grey, has brought these times to life for me.The story of Sini Toivola (whose surname is derived from the Finnish word for hope) tells of the brave Finnish women who needed two references to request membership in a group of intrepid grey-clad women, the Lotta Svärd, a paramilitary organization originally formed in 1918, who during the Second World War kept their tiny country running while all available men were "freed" to be conscripted into the army. The Svärd by 1944 numbered nearly 250,000 women, the largest volunteer auxiliary organization in the world. This was in a country that at the time numbered less than 4 million. As in London, children including my eldest sister in Helsinki and its environs were sent to Sweden for safety, many for the entirety of the war. Finnish men and women fought for their freedom, families, and way of life. While my mother served as a telegraph operator for the war department in Helsinki, the Lotta Svärd served at the air raid warning stations and hospitals as well as at the front. The author captures the unique feeling of life in Finland during this time, and although romance figures into this book, Lyons never glosses over the bitterness of war or the sacrifices that are required. The story deserves to be remembered and I am personally grateful to Annette Lyon for her well-written and engaging story. I highly recommend it....more

title: Dreams as Revelation
author: Woodger, Mary Jane
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have a family heritage of people who have dreams, which I have always found interesting. Dreams are often discounted as merely a part of our psyche I have a family heritage of people who have dreams, which I have always found interesting. Dreams are often discounted as merely a part of our psyche trying to mull through events of the day, but through experience I believe there is more to them. My mother, for instance, had a gift for knowing things. She told of a time during the Finnish Winter War when she was was suddenly awoken during the night to hear my father cry out her name. She recorded the time and day and anxiously awaited news from the battlefield. She was relieved but not surprised when a letter came from father. He had narrowly escaped death when a bomb exploded by him, creating a crater right where he stood as it sprayed shrapnel and killed his fellow soldier, but miraculously spared him. He wrote that he had called out her name at that moment. Coincidence? I think not.I have mixed feelings about this anthology. I really looked forward to reading it as there are so many interesting dreams that I have read about the early days of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The book is a collection by three authors, organized into chapter headings to categorize types of dreams such as dreams of warning, or prophecy, of comfort, and so forth. The book has an introduction by Robert L Millet, and two interesting introductory chapters, the first about how revelation is given in the form of dreams, the second discussing how to ascertain if your dreams are revelation. The book seems a bit hastily edited from this point on; dreams have sometimes been included only to bulk up a chapter while others are very interesting and even faith-promoting. The reader will find incidents which are famous in Latter-day Saint history, such as the dream of Joseph F. Smith, "I am Clean," and other treasures in the 284-page volume. In fact, if you want to find out whose dreams are included, there is a handy list of individuals to consult at the end of the book. As a reader, I wished there had been a more historical background and commentary for some of the more interesting dreams, whereas the authors only gave a brief introduction of each topic at the beginning of each chapter. I read it from cover to cover but it might be better as a reference work, especially if it had included an index. Here is a link to an interview with the authors: https://www.deseret.com/2019/7/26/893......more

title: The Age of Innocence
author: Wharton, Edith

review: One of my very favorite novels. I was thrilled to visit and tour the author’s home and library in Lenox, Massachusetts this past summer l. There at thOne of my very favorite novels. I was thrilled to visit and tour the author’s home and library in Lenox, Massachusetts this past summer l. There at the delightful gift shop I purchased a lovely Macmillan Collector’s pocket-sized gilt-edged edition with an introduction by Rachel Cusk. It’s a perfect size to carry on a journey.Some of my acquaintances read this in high school and hated it. I understand as it is not a book for any starry-eyed romantic. It more about the choices we make in life and how we see them as we look back. I happen to love the ending and find it very satisfying. But perhaps that is my age and my life experience speaking. The novel certainly deserved the Pulitzer Prize (1920) and is still bright and wry in its observations of human foibles and social commentary. Wharton’s eye for interesting dialogue and historical detail is impeccable. And as I just discovered, Edith Wharton writes so weep about the homes inhabited by her characters. She did understand beautiful homes. Her time and experience spent building her own home called The Mount, was one of the inspirations that also spurred her writing of of one of the finest books on design that is still studied today in interior design classes! The Age of Innocence is a novel that one can return to read every few years. Each decade it would be a new story, I believe. ...more

review: Every book has something to teach us. Sometimes it may be simply, that we don’t enjoy it and that it is all right not to finish it.The plot of the ArtEvery book has something to teach us. Sometimes it may be simply, that we don’t enjoy it and that it is all right not to finish it.The plot of the Art of Racing in the Rain was simple, yet at times lovely, and the dog, Enzo, and his owner, Denny, were endearing. However, It’s rather odd that today’s society needs to be taught how to behave and/or to solve problems through the voice of a dog. Have we really strayed that far from a personal or societal moral compass? Three quotes stood out for me:1. “Such a simple concept, it’s so true: that which we manifest is before us; we are the creators of our own destiny. Be it through intention or ignorance, our successes and our failures have been brought on by none other than ourselves.” 43-442. On pain: “. . . only dogs and women understand because we connect to pain directly from its source, and so it is at once brilliant and brutal and clear, like white-hot metal spraying out of a firehose, we can appreciate the aesthetic while taking the rest of it straight in the face. Men, on the other hand, are all filters and deflectors and timed release. For men, it’s like athletes foot: spray the special spray on it they say, and it goes away. They have no idea that the manifestation of their affliction-–the fungus between their hairy toes—is merely a symptom, an indication of a systemic problem.” 67-683. Enzo: “ I cannot speak, so I listen very well. I never interrupt, I never deflect the course of the conversation with a comment of my own. People, if you pay attention to them, change the direction of one another’s conversations constantly.” 109...more

review: I cannot say I continually loved reading this Pulitzer Prize winning novel. At times I would put it down for a week or two, overwhelmed at the plight I cannot say I continually loved reading this Pulitzer Prize winning novel. At times I would put it down for a week or two, overwhelmed at the plight of both the narrator, Lyman Ward, and his grandparents. It would catch my eye and draw me in again, and while I plowed through parts, at other times, the text sang out her truth and I didn't want the moment to end. I love Stegner's writing. It is powerful and poignant, truthful, and often lyrically beautiful. At times I felt as if I was reading a work by Flannery O'Conner, as horrific as Southern Grotesque, at other times, Stegner's voice smooths out into romance or drama, painted with the bold brushstrokes of Frida Kahlo, and at others, post-war baby boomers tossed around their revolutionary ideas .Deftly blended, this pioneer tale of the American West was so complex in its construction and satisfying in its outcome as Stegner unearthed the life of Lyman and his Grandparents and unravel the mysteries of the human heart. It is a masterpiece of American literature and keenly cognizant of the legacy of the dreamers who populated the West and how history ever repeats itself in one grand story....more

title: The Moonstone
author: Collins, Wilkie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Finally I finished this book. I very much enjoyed The Woman in White by Collins and thought this would be an excellent way to read more of Collins’ woFinally I finished this book. I very much enjoyed The Woman in White by Collins and thought this would be an excellent way to read more of Collins’ work. My edition had almost 500 pages printed in a very tiny font and was daunting to read but by the end I was enjoying the design and workmanship in the writing so much and now feel that it really is a “must read” for any serious student of mystery or detective novels. First published in as a 32-episode serial, The Moonstone debuted to great public anticipation and Charles Dickens, a lifelong friend of Collins, commented that it was “ A very curious story, wild and yet domestic with excellent character in it and great mystery.” Contemporaneous authors including Henry James praised it; T. S. Elliot called it “The first, the longest and the best of the modern English detective novel.”The introduction was fascinating as were the end notes which at times describe some of the research and background that Collins drew from in his writing. For the modern reader, I know that an abridged version might make this more palatable, but the meticulous way in which details are described in the novel are incredibly informative for any student of the Victorian era. Plus, the characters are delightfully drawn, and show us some of the humor, sentiment, and social commentary of the British Empire at its height. ...more

title: Misty of Chincoteague        (Misty, #1)
author: Henry, Marguerite
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved the books of Marguerite Henry in 4th grade. That was the year when the wonders of the bookmobile first appeared as it parked on the empty lot I loved the books of Marguerite Henry in 4th grade. That was the year when the wonders of the bookmobile first appeared as it parked on the empty lot kitty corner from where we lived on Sunnyside Road. One trip to the mobile library every two weeks didn’t suffice and I faithfully read everything I could tote home in two visits. Horses became a bit of an obsession after Henry’s delightful books. My imagination ran wild as I saved money to buy Dr. Barry’s series of horse training manuals and unsuccessfully begged my parents for permission to buy a pony to keep in the little garden shed in the back of our yard. Visiting my daughter in Maryland brought me full circle as we visited the island of the wild ponies a few weeks ago. Chincoteague is a National Park, whose sand dunes, marsh, and forest protect the northern Maryland coast from the buffeting storms of the Atlantic Ocean. Filled with birds and wildlife and edged with beaches, the island is a natural haven and a highly favored summer tourist destination. History suggests that in 1750 a Spanish galleon, La Galla, was shipwrecked off the island in a storm and the first island ponies were survivors of that tragedy. Henry has deftly integrated the history of the ponies into her story, including the yearly tradition of the pony roundup. As we stood on a wooden pier hoping for a glimpse, we were rewarded by a herd watched over by a chestnut stallion. One lovely brown and white pinto mare and her foal waded with the herd across the marshy bay to where we stood. The mare grazed peacefully as tourists snapped photos. Her foal rolled around in marsh grass, scratched herself on the bushes and explored the little island off the pier. Magical. ...more

review: Having grown up immersed in Finnish folk tales, I was very curious about this book. Loved the cover art. The elements of culture and magic in the storHaving grown up immersed in Finnish folk tales, I was very curious about this book. Loved the cover art. The elements of culture and magic in the story of Aino add insight into the Kalevala myth, including the foolishness of pride, finding true love and vanquishing one’s opponent. The characters of the book including the maiden Aino and her impetuous brother, Jakko, as well as Vane, the wizard, and the silly mother are well-drawn and comfortably fit into the required characters in many of the old Finnish tales. Overall, the story was well written, but the ending felt a bit perfunctory and hurried. I would like to see the book culminate back at its beginning as Joseph Campbell has pointed out that a hero journey should. I was also distracted by the last section of the book with its multiple editing issues and consequently lowered my rating to 3 1/2 stars. I wish that the author would get this reprinted in a new edition. ...more

author: Morris, Heather*

review: Umm. There are so many excellent books on the Holocaust, but I couldn’t really classify this as one of them. This novel is based upon the true survivaUmm. There are so many excellent books on the Holocaust, but I couldn’t really classify this as one of them. This novel is based upon the true survival story of Lale Sokolov, who innocently accepts an Nazi demand for each family to send one 18-year old to work for the German government. His world is turned upside down as he is transports on a cattle car, stripped of all that he has with him, and then is tattooed with his identifier number, 32407. Th story unfolds with Lale deciding to watch and learn how to survive, eventually gaining the post of the camp tattooist, a privileged, but also horrible assignment. The story unfolds in 268 pages and while it is gripping at times, as a reader, I felt that the horror of the holocaust and Lale’s motivations are not always given enough space to integrate into one another. I felt that the author wrote from a woman’s perspective and Lale’s character and motivations to survive were not always adequately addressed. It almost felt like a romance was written first and then the events of the holocaust was laid upon the bones of that story. I still recommend the book as a 3.5 but as stated, have my reservations about the writing of the story itself. ...more

review: This was a book I wanted to savor. With so much history and a rich storyline, I had this on my to-read list for several years. I really really wanted This was a book I wanted to savor. With so much history and a rich storyline, I had this on my to-read list for several years. I really really wanted to love Pachinko. I have many favorite Asian authors but this is my first experience with the story of a Korean family after Japanese occupation. Told in an omniscient voice, the story slips back and forth, as the author deftly weaves the lives of the characters into a rich tapestry of emotions and situations. Beginning with young and innocent Sunja who lives in a fishing village South Korea with her parents, the stories adds in several generations until we meet a grandson educated in America. They all deal with their Korean identity in unique ways. Many quotes stood out including, “Living every day in the presence of those who refuse to acknowledge your humanity takes great courage.” Lee is a gifted storyteller and pulls the reader into her narration. While this is a powerful and often beautifully written story, for me, some modern fiction writing pushes past my comfort level. The mature subject matter of some of the contemporary characters in the novel was too graphic for me personally and I skipped sections in order to finish the book.With this disclaimer, the novel has great wisdom and merit as long as you are conscious of your own limits....more

title: The River at Green Knowe        (Green Knowe, #3)
author: Boston, Lucy M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: No one writes about nature and the countryside as beautifully as do the British. Theirs is a long tradition of noticing, treasuring, and articulating No one writes about nature and the countryside as beautifully as do the British. Theirs is a long tradition of noticing, treasuring, and articulating beauty. I grew up with this series and as an adult am so impressed with the authors of this time, like Boston, who never thought to talk down to children in their writing. This volume, number three in the series, does not bring in the characters from the previous books. Instead it is comprised of adventures, sometimes magical, for three children who stay with a preoccupied archeologist and her cook at Green Knowe manor for a summer, with total freedom to explore the world around them. They canoe along the River Ouse, that runs past the banks of the property, and create a map of their discoveries on paper in the attic bedroom which they share. Filled with wonder and innocence, this was a delight to read again. Oh, for the days when kids were not over-scheduled and learned the happy talent for imaginary play outdoors!I am also happy to note that L.M. Boston’s daughter-in-law Diana Boston has been living in this home with its thousand year history and that one can visit the real house in England in Cambridgeshire Hemingford Grey. https://web.archive.org/web/201205090......more

author: Dillard, Annie

review: Picked this book up from a little free loan library box on the street above our summer home in Bellingham. I really enjoy Annie Dillard’s writing. It Picked this book up from a little free loan library box on the street above our summer home in Bellingham. I really enjoy Annie Dillard’s writing. It sometimes reminds me of the gothic writing of Flannery O’Connor with its quirky characters and details of the bizarre and often unexpectedly cruel nature of the natural world. An astute observer, Dillard has created a massive (397 page) historically accurate novel of the early settlers that migrated West, dropped off by watercraft on the narrow beaches that backed onto the inhospitable forested wilderness of Whatcom County, Washington. Beginning with the fictional Fishburns in 1855, we follow the varied fortunes of four families who labor against overwhelming odds, to survive in a fog-shrouded, verdant and untamed land with timber twelve feet across and no road access across the forbidding Coastal Range mountains. It was fascinating to ponder the lives that these hardy individuals painstakingly carve out over the next decades. ...more

title: March
author: Brooks, Geraldine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sometimes a book grabs you in a chokehold and refuses to let you go. This is one of them. I can't say that I loved this book, but I love the talent ofSometimes a book grabs you in a chokehold and refuses to let you go. This is one of them. I can't say that I loved this book, but I love the talent of Geraldine Brooks, who has won a Pulitzer for her novels but is equally talented in nonfiction, having been a war and foreign correspondent; she is so, so good as a writer. She does her research and writes with a strong, deft touch and with, what is said to be a "harrowing" brilliance. If you are looking for a sweet view of the patriarch of the March family, this fictionalized version of the Little Women's father modeled somewhat on Bronson Alcott, may not the book for you. Instead this is often a haunting and disturbing book about the idealistic Mr. March leaving his "little" women to heroically participate in war. Reading March is almost a visceral experience, a flaying open of the wounds caused by the experiences of war--an illumination of war's toll on the flawed men and women who are drawn into conflict for myriad reasons. As a history buff, I found the truths in this book to be both insightful and terrible. Beauty: "I had been there, on a spring morning, when the fog stood so thick on the river that it looked as though the bowl of the sky had spilled all its milky clouds into the valley." p.11Pain: "Somehow, I would have to unpack the anger and humiliation I carried in my breast, put it away, deep in an imaginary box, and store it somewhere on a high shelf of my heart where I would deal with it much later. I was not sure if I had the discipline to do it. Even to save him." 246...more

title: The Secret Chord
author: Brooks, Geraldine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** I have mixed feelings about this novel. Born out of a time that includes a loving but also vengeful God who could destroy villages a**spoiler alert** I have mixed feelings about this novel. Born out of a time that includes a loving but also vengeful God who could destroy villages and slay those who were not children of the covenant, this retelling may seem barbaric to the eyes of a modern reader who is looking for the kind God of the New Testament, but possibly more “true” in its feel than many of the stories I had grown up with. As a child I was smitten with the beautiful young shepherd boy who slew a giant Philistine, rose to prominence in King Saul’s court and then became king and the uniting force behind the Israelite people. Over the years I’ve learned to see David as much more complex and often flawed as a character than I ever imagined as a child. Some of my favorite passages include the fact that Bathsheba was not a “wanton” woman, rather that she was doing a common ritual cleansing in a mikveh on her rooftop when first seen by the King. I also loved the passages with David composing music for his God and weeping because of his own imperfections including the slaughter of Uriah and his indulgence to so many sons who competed for his crown. I was also taken with the beauty of the passages about the young heir, Solomon that were fictionalized but insightful as to possibly how this child of Bathsheba’s and protégé of the prophet Nathan grew into a wise and thoughtful ruler. Filled with beautiful passages that are a trademark of Brooks’ writing, this book also contains graphic images of war, rape and death. It’s there in the Old Testament and as we study the history of the time, the treatment of women, the subterfuge, the fratricide, etc, that are recorded are not pleasant but quite possibly historically accurate. So, as a reader I used my agency to skip over passages that were too much for me and by the end found that David’s story is ultimately redemptive. If you want a whitewashed story with noble characters, this is not recommended but as a reminder of the turbulent times that Israel grew out of, and how the God of Israel uses flawed individuals to further His purposes, it is well done....more

review: I was given this book in 1996 by my Aunt whom I was visiting in Helsinki, Finland. Born in Finland, I had emigrated with my family to Canada as a younI was given this book in 1996 by my Aunt whom I was visiting in Helsinki, Finland. Born in Finland, I had emigrated with my family to Canada as a young child. Although I still speak Finnish and have returned many times to travel through the country, I finally picked this book up on the 100th anniversary of Finnish Independence as I desired a better grounding the history of my ancestors. This book provides a basic outline of the factors that led to the development of the music, art, architecture, and literature of Finland. I loved this book as it helped contextualize so much of what my parents held up as important throughout my childhood. It has rekindled a desire to know even more of my heritage and begin to read some famous novels by Finnish authors as well as try to improve the reading of my mother tongue....more

review: Delightful. This slim volume contains nine essays that are at times hilarious (German trekkers), at times rhapsodic (jaunts through the woods and fielDelightful. This slim volume contains nine essays that are at times hilarious (German trekkers), at times rhapsodic (jaunts through the woods and fields) and prone to descriptive adjectives (a botanist's dream), but always exhibits a curious, intelligent mind with an astute eye for detail. Taken from essays that were originally published in 1903, there is much to love in this slim volume. Why did Lady Campbell feel that her outings were like prison breaks? Who are the twins that she mentions? What did society do with a lady who wanted to break from traditional pursuits and (gasp) learn to tame and ride a bicycle, happily enjoy a sudden overnight stay at a hotel away from home, tromp through a fish market complete with several inches of fish slime on the floor, or charm her way into a London train station's command center to find out how their system was automated? Totally charming and often very up-to-date....more

review: Absolutely one of the finest novels I have read this year. The characters are well-drawn and the plot twists and turns through historical events surroAbsolutely one of the finest novels I have read this year. The characters are well-drawn and the plot twists and turns through historical events surrounding the occupation of France by the German Reich during WWII. I have read many books on this topic but what makes this a standout is the viewpoint of the war from the women who were involved. One of the most poignant lines was "Men tell stories," I say. It is the truest, simplest answer to his question. "Women get on with it. For us it was a shadow war. There were no parades for us when it was over, no medals or mentions in history books. We did what we had to during the war, and when it was over, we picked up the pieces and started our lives over." [L.561]. My mother served for five years as a war communications telephone operator in Helsinki while engaged to my father who fought on the front lines. This novel elaborates on the truths about war, hardship, love, loneliness, and the courage that it took to survive through that time. Beautifully written and highly recommended....more

The author's portrayal of working class conditions of the time translate in my mind to similar work that we now outsource to many countries. There companies have similar working conditions for the women and children whom they employ. The era of sweatshop labor that is portrayed in this novel and in in movies such as North and South is unbelievably still alive and well. My favorite quote in this novel was "Perhaps you're too young yet to see how the tides go in and out. For all the wealth and luxury in this house, there's nothing magical about it. review: As a child I recall looking at a mustard seed encased in resin that my Sunday School teacher held up in class as she recounted the idea that if we hadAs a child I recall looking at a mustard seed encased in resin that my Sunday School teacher held up in class as she recounted the idea that if we had faith the size of this lowly and minute mustard seed, we could move mountains. I remember contemplating what this idea entailed. But no one ever really explained what faith was, and I wondered how to apply this idea in my own life until I read parts of these lectures years years later. Originally a part of the Doctrine and Covenants, these doctrinal ideas were taught by the Prophet Joseph Smith to the School of the Prophets in Kirtland, Ohio in about 1834-35, and later were later recorded by Sidney Rigdon with Joseph's input and corrections. These theological lectures cover questions such as, Why is Christ called "the author and finisher of our faith?" Why is faith essential and what is faith and how do we obtain it? Every decade that I live, my understanding of this principle grows. Life experience and desire definitely help me to comprehend this book better. Brilliant book--it is the mustard seed upon which our understanding of faith can grow. ...more

review: Without BoundariesThe story of one of the most accomplished birder in the world, was a mixed read for me. At times I felt that the author repeated herWithout BoundariesThe story of one of the most accomplished birder in the world, was a mixed read for me. At times I felt that the author repeated herself and that the writing was not as sophisticated as I had hoped. Yet, the subject of the story, Phoebe Snetsinger, is a complex, driven, and fascinating woman. Although perhaps not in “touch” with her deeper feelings, according to the author, her ability to focus on her love of birds drove her many years past a cancer diagnosis and many mishaps and traumatic events to become the first person to break the 8,000 bird species ceiling.My favorite parts of this book include the descriptions of Phoebe’s travels around the world as well as the birds that Amy sought out on he trips. I found her relationship with her family to be difficult to understand as it always seemed to be in second place behind her birding goals, but perhaps in order to achieve something of this magnitude, a ferocious single mindedness is necessary. As a casual birder with a life list under 500, I now realize how much I am missing. This biography inspired me to go on another guide birding trip in the future....more

From India to Ethiopia and the United States, we follow the narrator as he attempts to recount his family history and the small decisions that change the course of his life over fifty decades. The voice of Marion as the narrator is gentle, then suddenly veers to brittle, and oftentimes rises to brilliant. So many choice passages in this this novel. review: Watched the series when it first came out and enjoyed it so I began on the books and read all 12 over the summer. Winston Graham is a first-rate authoWatched the series when it first came out and enjoyed it so I began on the books and read all 12 over the summer. Winston Graham is a first-rate author. The books cover a period of time from 1776 and the American revolution through 1812 and the Napoleonic Wars. I enjoyed the historical aspects of the novels, although in a few of the stories the political sections got a little over-long for a leisure read so I skimmed them, only to come back to reread as I wanted to know what happened. I found the characters, especially the Polark family, to be well-drawn, compelling, and complex. They have human foibles and at times I was frustrated with the decisions that they would make to the point of not wanting to read what I anticipated would occur next, which is for me, a sign of an engaging text. Graham wrote the first four books in the series and then years later wanted to find out what happened to his characters and wrote another eight, so it was quite a time commitment to read the complete series. Definitely worth it if you are a quick reader. The books are lengthy so each book took several days to read. Overall, the Poldarks are one of my new favorite literary families. The books are full of pithy quotes and lovely writing:"They spoke little, all preferring to keep their own thoughts tight and tidy and untouched."...more

title: Key to the Science of Theology
author: Pratt, Parley P.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: To appreciate this book, we have to first understand and contextualize it as a by-product of a remarkable time--the restoration of the Gospel during aTo appreciate this book, we have to first understand and contextualize it as a by-product of a remarkable time--the restoration of the Gospel during a time of great advances in knowledge. Written in the passionate, often poetic style of the mid-1800s by Elder Parley Parker Pratt, who joined the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints just five months after it had been organized on April 6, 1830, the book touches on a broad array of ideas ranging from the purpose of government, through the creation of the universe, the purpose of science and the arts, and of course, the mysteries of the Godhead. An indefatigable missionary and writer, Elder Pratt wanted members throughout the fledgling Church to know about the concepts that the Prophet taught. So Pratt wrote countless missionary tracts, books including the History of the Missouri Persecutions, and founded the Millennial Star, the oldest publication issued by the Church. He served numerous missions, was imprisoned for his views, as well called as an apostle on the first Council of Twelve for the Church along with his brother Orson Pratt. To know more about his remarkable life, I would recommend the Autobiography of Parley P. Pratt (Deseret Book, 1874). This book is fascinating as it shows how the time Elder Pratt spent with the Prophet Joseph Smith broadened his vision of what life holds for the follower of Christ. For Elder Pratt, truth was all encompassed within the Gospel--all part of what he called the science of theology. Some of the most interesting chapters span the second half of the book, including ruminations on the powers and calling of angels, the divine nature of dreams, qualifications for understanding the "science" of theology, the differentiation of spirits, and the power of miracles. Some members of the Church may not feel that there is anything new here, but a careful contextualization reminds us that these ideas were for the time, almost unimaginable and often breathtaking in their scope. The book has many often quoted passages including a personal favorite on the refining influence of the Holy Ghost: "It quickens all the intellectual faculties, increases, enlarges, expands and purifies all the natural passions and affections, and adapts them, by the gift of wisdom to their lawful use. It inspires, develops, cultivates and matures all the fine toned sympathies, joys, tastes, kindred feelings and affections of our nature. It inspires virtue, kindness, goodness, tenderness, gentleness and charity. It develops beauty of person, form and features. It tends to health, vigor, animation and social feeling. It develops and invigorates all the faculties of the physical and intellectual man. It strengthens, invigorates and gives tone to the nerves. In short, it is, as it were marrow to the bone, joy to the heart, light to the eyes, music to the ears, and life to the whole being."...more

review: I thoroughly enjoyed John Adams as well as 1776 by McCullough, but for my reading style made a mistake by attempting to listen to this book on AudibleI thoroughly enjoyed John Adams as well as 1776 by McCullough, but for my reading style made a mistake by attempting to listen to this book on Audible. Over 17 hours of narration long, the Greater Journey, literally dragged on for almost a year. There is so much of interest from politics and medicine, through architecture, fashion, and fine art in this expansive retelling of a time period (approx. 1830-1900) when everything worthwhile appeared to be found on the Continent, especially in Paris, the City of Lights. As I generally can read so quickly, I found myself bogged down as I listened and then discovered that speeding up the reading ruined the storytelling for me. The moral of my experience is that paper texts have an actual landscape that one can return to, an experience that is unavailable to a listener. Plus, this is a book I would have enjoyed much better if I could have annotated it. I will probably want to revisit it in paperback....more

title: Medical Medium: Secrets Behind Chronic and Mystery Illness and How to Finally Heal
author: William, Anthony
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have followed Anthony Williams Facebook page called Medical Medium, for quite some time as I like to learn about the properties of good foods--fruitI have followed Anthony Williams Facebook page called Medical Medium, for quite some time as I like to learn about the properties of good foods--fruits, vegetables, spices, and herbs. He is called an "intuitive" healer like Edgar Case in the early 1900s. A lot of what he has to say makes sense and follows mindful eating habits and the Word of Wisdom. I used his celery cleanse, for instance, and felt fabulous. He feels that the new so-called mystery illnesses like fibromyalgia, Epstein-Barr, rheumatoid arthritis, Lyme Disease, and chronic fatigue can be healed by a cleansing diet of lots of (you guessed it), fruits and vegetables. He also posits a case for super mutating viruses like CMV as the root of many of these unexplained illnesses. Healthy people may have these viruses in them (over 60% of American grownups, for instance has CMV) but when stress and illness strike, they predispose people to exhibit these ailments which are then hard to diagnose and cure. Another issue that causes the body to get out of balance according to Anthony is the overuse of "super-antibiotics" that play havoc with the human biome.Practical and easy to follow suggestions. Who am I to quibble? He is a quiet, non-flashy guy who now has about a million FB followers and tons of testimonials from people including Hollywood stars who feel that he has helped them to heal from chronic illnesses....more

title: The Hare With Amber Eyes: A Family's Century of Art and Loss
author: de Waal, Edmund
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A slow, meticulous reader who enjoys art and culture would love this book. It concerns the rise of the Ephrussi house, a wealthy Jewish family who comA slow, meticulous reader who enjoys art and culture would love this book. It concerns the rise of the Ephrussi house, a wealthy Jewish family who come as grain merchants from Odessa, Russia to cities including Paris and Vienna in the mid 1800s. They experience incredible success in business and begin collecting art as they build grand homes. During this time, one of the early family members buys several hundred netsuke figurines from Japan as part of his penchant for collecting. As the decades pass the family is at times honored and adored and then castigated and hated because of their race. The threads of the story are woven together into a tapestry by a contemporary family member, a successful potter, who has inherited the netsuke. The author has a wonderful voice and an incredible eye for detail as he travels around Europe and beyond to follow the history of the netsuke as it passes through the scions of the family into contemporary times. “Stories are a kind of thing, too. Stories and objects share something, a patina. I thought I had this clear, two years ago before I started, but I am no longer sure how this works. Perhaps a patina is a process of rubbing back so that the essential is revealed, the way that a striated stone tumbled in a river feels irreducible, the way that this netsuke of a fox has become little more than a memory of a nose and a tail. But it also seems additive, in the way that a piece of oak furniture gains over years and years of polishing, and the way the leaves of my medlar shine.” “Yangi, a philosopher, art historian and poet, had evolved a theory of why some objects - pots, baskets, cloth made by unknown craftsmen - were so beautiful. In his view, they expressed unconscious beauty because they had been made in such numbers that the craftsman had been liberated from his ego.” ...more

review: After visiting Quebec City last week I was intrigued to know more about the history of the French in the northeast. As we drove through Kennebunkport After visiting Quebec City last week I was intrigued to know more about the history of the French in the northeast. As we drove through Kennebunkport Maine a couple of days later, a collectible bookshop caught my eye. This was one of my delightful purchases. Published in 1906, this book in Amanda Douglas' Little Girl series was an interesting view of the history of the founding of Quebec City, especially as it was written from the viewpoint of a woman living several centuries later. The heroine, Rose, is portrayed as an independent girl, the "Rose of Old Quebec" at a time when the Victorian restrictions on women were still very much a daily reality for the author. I wonder if Douglas was a suffragette? Hmm. It is fascinating to see the world, real or imagined, through an author's eyes. title: Bel Canto
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Luminous novel. Although I felt that the Epilogue was not the strongest part of the novel, the rest of this story is lovely. Wound around themes such Luminous novel. Although I felt that the Epilogue was not the strongest part of the novel, the rest of this story is lovely. Wound around themes such as the passage of time, religious faith, what it means to be literate, and especially the power of art, beauty, and music to change our lives, Bel Canto (which translates to "beautiful singing") is an enchanting view of what it means to be human under trying circumstances. Opera and classical music have been in my home once childhood and the thrill of sitting in an opera house as the orchestra warms up and the light dim is palpable delight at its best. Consequently I was surprised at how the author, who admits to only recently beginning her admiration for this art form, is able to make it sound so authentic and integral to this story. Without a retelling of the plot, I will state that the book actually reads like an opera on many levels. Katsumi Hosokawa recalls how his life forever changed after his father took him to see Verdi's Rigoletto as a child. From that point on, "There was nothing more to want than the privilege to sit and listen." His favorite recording star is Roxane Coss, modeled on lyric soprano Renée Fleming. Pachett's descriptions are at times, exquisite: "Her voice was so pure, so light, that it opened up the ceiling and carried their petitions directly to God. It swept over them like the feathery dusting of wings, so that even the Catholics who no longer practiced their faith, and the non-Catholics who came along because there was nothing else to do, and all those who had no idea what he was saying, and the stone-cold atheists who wouldn't have cared anyway, because of her singing they all went away feeling moved, feeling comforted, feeling, perhaps, the slightest tremors of faith." 200. As Roxane exults, "who did not feel the joy in such music?"This book contains so much to examine (references to music abound), to savor and contemplate that it has earned a spot on my bookshelf. ...more

This one was also loosely based around the Scottish King James who was iMy favorite novels by Kearsley are by far The Rose Garden and The Winter Sea. This one was also loosely based around the Scottish King James who was in exile in Paris in the 1700s. Kearsley's writing reminds me of my favorite gothic romance writers as a teen--Mary Stewart and Daphne Du Maurier. When I want something light to read, these fit the ticket, especially as they also contain researched history. This novel concerns a brilliant young English woman with Asperger's Syndrome who is asked to travel to Paris crack a code in an old diary. The diary, kept by a Jacobite exile (somewhere during 1688-1746), Mary Dundas, contains unexpected information about the time period as well as a grand adventure and coming of age for both women involved. ...more

title: The Black Rose
author: Costain, Thomas B.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When my Father died in 1991, he left behind a stash of Thomas B Costain novels. Even as a young girl, I remember looking at these books which always aWhen my Father died in 1991, he left behind a stash of Thomas B Costain novels. Even as a young girl, I remember looking at these books which always appealed to me because of their titles. This 1946 bestseller about Walter a Gurney, a young bastard son of a noble is a fascinating look back into English history in the 1200s. Costain draws on a legend of an English crusader who becomes the father of Thomas a Beckett, and an Eastern girl who only knows two words of English. Costain began the book wanting to write about three individuals: Edward I, King of England; the scientist and visionary thinker, Roger Bacon; and a Mongolian general named Bayon of the Hundred Eyes, who conquered China for Kublai Khan. While the book only deals with these three individuals in a peripheral way, and although dated due to 1940s stereotypes and writing style, this was still a fascinating, though romanticized look into the Dark Ages including changes in the feudal system of England, the advent of the longbow and discovery of gunpowder, as well as the beginning of enlightenment due to the intrepid explorers who returned from fabled Cathay....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A Haggadah is historically read at the Passover feast by the Jewish people. This one is different. Originating in Spain in the late 1400s, the vellum A Haggadah is historically read at the Passover feast by the Jewish people. This one is different. Originating in Spain in the late 1400s, the vellum manuscript stands out because it is illustrated, and in the exquisite illuminated style created by medieval Catholic monks. How it ends up in Sarajevo in the mid 1990s is a miracle. A very interesting read for anyone who loves book preservation, history, and historical fiction. I especially love the article Brooks wrote about this Haggadah and its history. http://geraldinebrooks.com/wp-content...Quotations:"I like matter, fiber, the nature of the varied stuffs that go to make a book. I know the flesh and fabric of pages, the bright earths and lethal toxins of ancient pigments. Wheat paste--I can bore the pants off anyone about wheat paste." (18)"I was so engrossed in the writing long – it could get that way, on good days, when you fall down a rabbit hole and the rest of the world disappears long – that I almost exploded when the doorbell rang." title: Pope Joan

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Extraordinary historical fiction piece set in the Dark Ages, about a brilliant and prodigious intellect, Joan, who hungers for an education in an age Extraordinary historical fiction piece set in the Dark Ages, about a brilliant and prodigious intellect, Joan, who hungers for an education in an age where women were thought of as chattel and reading and writing were reserved for priests and noblemen. Knowledge is power, or as her tutor tells her, "some ideas are dangerous." Having mastered Greek, Latin, classical scholarly debate, scriptural knowledge and knowledge of medicine and healing, Joan breaks the mold of women being "incapable of reasoning." (82) The book is an argument for the existence of a female pope as we follow Joan's journey to the highest office of Christendom after the death of Leo III. In a time where education is taken for granted and few students desire to work to the limits of their abilities, this book challenges a reader to reevaluate the gift of learning. Fascinating book about ideas and a little known historical era....more

review: Short, simple, and actually easy to incorporate some of into our lives. Scott asks for a 7% commitment of change for 28 days. That's easy. The common American processed food diet is basically composed of dead food. When I feel the best, I eat as my European parents did--lots of fresh (homegrown if possible) fruit and veggies, soups, and simple meals. I've recently added naturally fermented foods back in to my diet including kefir, sauerkraut, and homemade pickles and beets. Scott is not a food fanatic and he is funny, for instance, referring to the smell of milk as reminding him somehow of "coagulated cow mucus". author: Halpern, Marc
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In droves, people who have not found relief from Western medical treatments, are turning to complementary therapies such as 4,500 year old Ayurveduc kIn droves, people who have not found relief from Western medical treatments, are turning to complementary therapies such as 4,500 year old Ayurveduc knowledge. Our medical schools are increasingly offering courses in these modalities to round out a physician's training. I am an integrationist (find all helpful truths and use them) and feel that one method or school of thought seldom has all of the answers. Halpern's book offers a window to a different, wholistic way of looking at the body and especially illness as "dis-ease". When we are not in balance illness often will manifest itself. And sadly, what we do in Western medicine often addresses only symptoms and not causes, thereby creating further complications. Medicine is often an "art," not an exact science. For instance see the following article from the NYTimes that explains a little of what wide-spectrum antibiotics have done. Such a shame when if we searched for a root cause, we would be more likely to eliminate the illness. http://nyti.ms/1ygUdWW...more

review: Sadly, I was not as enamored with this historical romance as I had hoped to be. McNees' book was a good attempt to fill in a missing year of Alcott's Sadly, I was not as enamored with this historical romance as I had hoped to be. McNees' book was a good attempt to fill in a missing year of Alcott's life and address some of the reasons why she became such an independent writer. The romance was fine but my favorite parts were the historical details which were woven throughout the story. I loved the LMA books as a child and read and reread Little Women. It is one of the books that still sits on my bookshelf alongside L.M. Montgomery's "Anne of Green Gables". As an aside, I was invited to speak on Louisa's "other" writings a few years ago and just noticed that there is a newer title book about this subject: "Behind a Mask: The Unknown Thrillers of Louisa May Alcott". The Transcendentalist movement, the Walden Pond experiment and Louisa's father, Bronson Alcott and his role in the group is fascinating to explore. A book that I use as a reference work is "A Hunger for Home: Louisa May Alcott's Place in American Culture" by Sarah Elbert. ...more

review: I finally had a chance on a speaking assignment to visit Boston, MA, a city that has always intrigued me. While there, my husband and I walked the strI finally had a chance on a speaking assignment to visit Boston, MA, a city that has always intrigued me. While there, my husband and I walked the streets to discover the history of the era and fell in love with the area. Venerable Harvard University across the river, the park where Robert McCloskey's children's classic "Make Way for Ducklings" takes place, the bar where the television series Cheers was filmed, a tour of the harbor along with the battleship, The Constitution . . . But nothing left as much of an impression as the history of the revolution and the founding fathers. I had to read this book and have fallen in love with the brilliantly colored second president of our nation and framer of the constitution, John Adams. His New England constitution and sensibilities completely won me over, including his vanity and temper when young, his brilliant mind, love of reading and learning, his adventures in Europe, and most of all, his positive outlook as an elder statesman and love of his wife, Abigail, of family and friends. Fabulous book. Thanks David McCulloch. This was too long on my "to read" list. Highly recommend. ...more

title: How to be Lovely: The Audrey Hepburn Way of Life
author: Hellstern, Melissa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A gift from my daughter, this is a book of snippets including quotations by Audrey set apart by photographs. Not really an autobiography, rather this A gift from my daughter, this is a book of snippets including quotations by Audrey set apart by photographs. Not really an autobiography, rather this might be considered a little book of wisdom on how to live graciously. For me, watching old movies starring either of the Hepburns--Katharine or Audrey--was a tutorial on learning to live one's life in an authentic way. They were as different as could be in personality, yet both had an impact upon me as an impressionable young girl. In an era when discreet was still in vogue, Audrey Hepburn finished out her life quietly, creating beauty, caring for her husband and two sons, her home, her garden, and impoverished children around the world as an ambassador for UNICEF. Quotations: "What would it be like to die and look back miserably--seeing only the bad things, the opportunities missed, or what could have been.""There's a curious thing about pain or hardship. In the beginning it's an enemy, it's something you don't want to face or think about or deal with. Yet, with time it becomes almost a friend.""The world has always been cynical, and I think I'm a romantic at heart. I hope for better things, and I thank God the world is also full of people who want to be genuine and kind."...more

title: Archangel        (Samaria, #1)
author: Shinn, Sharon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've read this book several times over the years. If this 1996 novel had been introduced to me only with its basic plot, I would have probably not beeI've read this book several times over the years. If this 1996 novel had been introduced to me only with its basic plot, I would have probably not been very interested (proud and rebellious heroine meets dark, brooding archangel) but it is often delightful and resonates with me due to the characters as well as references to biblical texts that Shinn incorporates. A sci-fi-fantasy, the world that Shinn creates within the pages of her novel is both a unique and provocative look at religion, faith, and opposition in all things. It is romantic, philosophical, and spiritual in the larger than life way of an epic, but also warm and intimate. In a country called Samaria, a race of angels lives among humans. Appointed as guardians to the human race by their god, Jovah, the angels are beset by the same personality flaws and frailties as humans. The associative way that Shinn writes, bringing in geographic details and names such as Lucifer, Tamar, Bethel, and the ideas that drive the plot--how gods, angels, and mortals live and interact--are thought-provoking. The book reminds me of ideas found in the Urantia, the newly discovered Ethiopian version of the Book of Enoch, as well as other pseudographical volumes....more

title: The Lacuna
author: Kingsolver, Barbara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “An imperfectly remembered life is a useless treachery. Every day, more fragments of the past roll around heavily in the chambers of an empty brain, s“An imperfectly remembered life is a useless treachery. Every day, more fragments of the past roll around heavily in the chambers of an empty brain, shedding bits of color, a sentence or a fragrance, something that changes and then disappears. It drops like a stone to the bottom of the cave.”This novel was a serendipitous read as we work currently for an NGO in Eastern Europe that promotes international development in post-communist countries. Having just returned from Europe, I found myself at the airport bookstore searching for a book as we headed for the Yucatán peninsula for a vacation. I picked up Lacuna, by a favorite author, Barbara Kingsolver, and I was not disappointed, especially once I explored the cenotes and snorkeled in the underground rivers that are found throughout the Yucatán. An ambitious work, while sadly eschewed by some critics, Lacuna offers a unique and brilliant lens for looking at a tumultuous time in 20th Century history. I thoroughly enjoyed Kingsolver’s use of multiple narrational viewpoints to understand the worker’s movement and it’s appeal to human rights activists such as Leon Trotsky and the artist Diego Rivera and appreciated her research on this topic that was so assumed to be black and white for US citizens raised in the post WWII era. History repeats itself when we do not understand the past. review: I took my time with this book and read it, generally a chapter now and then when the mood struck me through a year, leisurely traveling along with theI took my time with this book and read it, generally a chapter now and then when the mood struck me through a year, leisurely traveling along with the author to find blue sheep and an elusive snow leopard in the depths of the Himalayas. Beautifully fashioned, it really has left me with a feeling of a moment in time. We see the author struggling along his Tibetan journey with physical dangers as well as psychological ones--the loss of his wife, his spirituality, his feelings of duty (reminds me of Cicero's lecture on the subject to his son), and much more. There are so many moments in this book that are revelatory, but this is definitely not for readers who want a fast plot and "stuff that happens". The descriptions of the journey are what the book is about, perhaps. There is an ending, but it is almost anticlimactic after meeting the characters along the path. It's a book to read and savor slowly and highlight. I don't think I would have appreciated it as much if I had read it earlier as I did at this point in my own life journey. ...more

She has read all of the extant versions available and then written this tale. Part fiction, mixed with doses of authorial interpretation, the story is written in a formal tone, and well-told. All of the familiar characters are fleshed out and Robin, in particular is very originally conceived. Strong women characters appear, which is also a hallmark of McKinley's writing.Perhaps the introduction was over-long, especially for those who want a plot-driven, rather than a character-driven study. review: It's not often I dislike the characters but still love the book. This novel is conflicted, beautiful, irritating, and really quite brilliant. If you rIt's not often I dislike the characters but still love the book. This novel is conflicted, beautiful, irritating, and really quite brilliant. If you read it as a gothic romance, that works. The beginning paragraph is flawless. The description of Manderley when the narrator first arrives is gorgeous. Personally I read it as a psychological exploration of women, with Rebecca and the unnamed narrator acting as foils/mirrors of one another. They are the red queen-white queen locked in a strange Alice in Wonderland world. Suspenseful, haunting, sometimes a little over the top, yet once the plot starts to unfold it veritably gallops along to an unexpected conclusion. Lots to discuss with this one and many good s discuss literary aspects worth exploring. No wonder Alfred Hitchcock chose to make a film from the novel.I’ve read this at 20, 40, and now in my 60s. It’s still just brilliant but it’s incredible what happens to my reactions as the narration unfolds. The relationship that I have with the narrator is changed radically with every two decades.
