review: I really don't know what to rate this book. Auuugh, I am conflicted. It is on one hand brash and slightly crude (think of a stereotypical adolescent mI really don't know what to rate this book. Auuugh, I am conflicted. It is on one hand brash and slightly crude (think of a stereotypical adolescent male brain) and on the other, inventive, creative and quite brilliant. It reminds me a lot of Catcher in the Rye for some strange reason. A bildungsroman perhaps? Anyway, I loved Holly's , which is spot on including how one may unexpectedly experience high school giggles at times while reading. I am old school and grew up thinking that swearing was an attempt at machismo from either young adults or uneducated individuals--in fact I almost find expressions such as "fudge" or "fug" worse than the real expletive as they are an attempt to get around the stigma of swearing in an irritatingly cloying way. But that is also Green's genius as he perfectly captures a form of adolescent boy talk typified in the relationship between protagonist, Colin, and his slightly chubby "male boobs" friend and sidekick, Hassan--sexual innuendos and potty humor, brashness, put downs, and more. Yet Colin is also brilliant and socially awkward and Hassan is bright, lovable, but lazy. Their banter is often intelligent. The use of "fug" for instance, is a literary reference, which makes it amusing as do the French and German expressions including sitzpinklery. At time I wanted to give up reading in disgust at the immaturity of the boys, and at the next, was drawn back in to see if they would grow up. That is Green's talent. While I really can recommend "Fault in Our Stars" this novel will not suit all readers. ...more

review: While not the "deepest" book that I have read on the topic of finding balance in our technology-filled lives, I enjoyed many of the ideas and must sayWhile not the "deepest" book that I have read on the topic of finding balance in our technology-filled lives, I enjoyed many of the ideas and must say that the way that Powers set up his handbook with illustrations from seven historical figures including Thoreau (finding our Walden zones) and Ben Franklin (creating positive rituals) was delightful. For instance, reading about Guttenburg's business enterprises Including mass-producing mirrors for capturing spiritual emanations at Aachen was humorous and engaging. Each chapter addressed communicative technology through the ages--with every advance, mankind has had to come to terms with how this can be used to enhance, not overload our lives with more work.My primary interest is often books and the topic of reading, and there was much in this book to ponder and many quotes to record. I don't know that the book changed my life, rather that it reminded me of why I have set up guidelines for myself of when to answer my phone, how I deal with email, why I have weekends as technology-free as possible--all so that I can be present with family and friends, find time for that interiority that we desperately need in order to have a rich and meaningful existence, rather than a superficial one. "The best human creativity, however, happens only when we have the time and mental space to take a new thought and follow it wherever it leads. William James once contrasted "the sustained attention of the genius, sticking to his subject for hours together," with the "commonplace mind" that flits from place to place." 60-61. review: I absolutely love this slim volume of collected teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith and have both read it through from cover to cover as well as usiI absolutely love this slim volume of collected teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith and have both read it through from cover to cover as well as using it as a reference for questions that I have had. It is just remarkable and shows the inspiration that stood behind Joseph Smith's teachings. The doctrines are set out in a way that we can both comprehend the character of God and learn what it takes to progress in our lives to become more Christ-like in our character.“If men do not comprehend the character of God, they do not comprehend themselves.” ( History of the Church, 6:303. ) “When you feel pure intelligence flowing into you, it may give you sudden strokes of ideas, so that by noticing it, you may find it fulfilled the same day or soon; (i.e.) those things that were presented unto your minds by the Spirit of God, will come to pass; and thus by learning the Spirit of God and understanding it, you may grow into the principle of revelation, until you become perfect in Christ Jesus.” ( Teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith, sel. Joseph Fielding Smith [1976], 151.) “We came to this earth that we might have a body and present it pure before God in the celestial kingdom. The great principle of happiness consists in having a body. The devil has no body, and herein is his punishment. He is pleased when he can obtain the tabernacle of man. . . . All beings who have bodies have power over those who have not.” ( Teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith, sel. Joseph Fielding Smith [1976], 181.) Although the Joseph Smith Papers have filled in a lot more than this ever could have addressed, it still stands by the "standard works" of religion on my bookshelf. It contains mind-expanding restored doctrine of who we are and why we are experiencing mortality with all of its highs and lows. It gives the reader so much Hope. I agree with Joe Hunt that it just gets better, the further you read in this volume. The doctrines are mind-blowing. It's why I became a member of this church as a 10-year old and have never looked back or regretted my decision.“Surely I have contemplated the things of God.” ( History of the Church 5:554 )...more

title: The Queen's Confession
author: Holt, Victoria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As a child I remember my sister loving Jean Plaidy and historical fiction. Well, Victoria Holt, is another pen name for the same author. I love historAs a child I remember my sister loving Jean Plaidy and historical fiction. Well, Victoria Holt, is another pen name for the same author. I love history and do enjoy this genre, as long as it is well written. Holt has done fastidious homework and while much of the intimate detail is fictionalized, Marie Antoinette and the circumstances of the French Revolution are drawn in great detail, from the historical events down to fantastic three-foot high hairstyles and her love of beautiful gowns to the little country home, the Trianon, that she had built on the grounds of Versailles to live her conception of pastoral idyllic life. As one who hated the super-conflated etiquette of the French court, Marie was so ill-suited to the manipulations and contrivances of the age and escaped reality and restriction to Trianon whenever she could. Understanding that she was so young and high-spirited allows the reader to see the tragic train of events unfolding. She and Louis XVI, her husband are tragic characters in a hate-filled, hysterical time that is often romanticized by modern shows such as Les Miserables. Excess, greed, avarice--all the classic seven sins are apparent in this era, but also the sweetness of human bonds. As a character and actual historical personage, Marie is most interesting. She had a happy childhood as the last of fifteen children, born to the Empress of Austria. Growing up in a life of privilege and wealth as an archduchess in Schonbruun Palace, Marie was completely unaware of the world around her and once transported to France as part of an "alliance" pact as a very young teen, she was supposed to immediately consummate her marriage with an equally young Louis to bear an heir, a dauphin, for France. As a foreigner to the court, she was high-spirited, headstrong, and had no idea of the money that she spent or of her detractors which put her in a dangerous position from the very beginning. Although she matures with motherhood, the French people saw her as the scapegoat for the excesses of the nobility that had magnified after the death of Louise IV. Mostly she refused to heed the advice of Mercy, the councilor that was appointed to advice her by her mother. Each chapter begins with quotations for documents of the time, including Marie's copious journals, letters, and memoirs, which center the events. I would recommend this highly but with the caution to read other accounts of her life to get a more complete picture. History is very subjective and as a historian friend reminds me, corroboration of sources is essential. ...more

review: After so many recommendations I finally tried this book, technically listed as an urban fantasy, or more specifically, a paranormal urban fantasy and After so many recommendations I finally tried this book, technically listed as an urban fantasy, or more specifically, a paranormal urban fantasy and put it down after the first chapter, thinking, great opening line, but a little edgy for my tastes. Hmm. My first attempt at urban fantasy. . . I have to admit I am not a big Twilight/vampire fan, yet really enjoyed The Host by Stephanie Meyer. But I finally picked it up a week later after hearing yet another person rave about it at an English teachers' convention. And, I have to say that upon completing it, I'll admit that I enjoyed it after the initial chapters--but that is the kind of reader that I am--it takes me a while to "like" a book. Lani Taylor's work is beautifully crafted and filled with memorable imagery and lines. The characters are exquisitely drawn and after a month, I still can "see" them and feel. If I know them--quite a feat in a YA market filled with cloned characters. Original in its conception, the storyline is engaging and moves quickly. Yes, it is romantic, but when one considers the primary audience--young women who are die-hard romantics, it fits the expectations of the genre. I don't think that this is a younger set YA novel as it is more mature in its themes, but considering the unique take on the age-old conflict between good and evil, this book merits consideration.A quote from the book:"Errand requiring immediate attention. Come.The note was on vellum, pierced by the talons of the almost-crow that delivered it. Karou read the message. 'He never says please', she sighed, but she gathered up her things.When Brimstone called, she always came."...more

review: I bought my copy of this book several decades ago and fnally read this up at a ranch near the High Unintas. Perfect, sad Western book. This one remindI bought my copy of this book several decades ago and fnally read this up at a ranch near the High Unintas. Perfect, sad Western book. This one reminds me so much of Cormac McCarthy's writing in how lean and spare the prose is, but is much more accessible for teens. My copy says that the reading level is fourth frade and it is recommended for age ten and up. I am not sure that I would recommend this to a young child? It is a series of vignettes from the life of a young boy, Jody, growing up on a ranch near Salinas, California. Like Annie Dillard's prose, most of the stories are filled with the unsympathetic violence of nature and definitely leave the reader with an unsettled feeling. Yet, Steinbeck at his best is a precise and beautiful craftsman as a writern with an ear for the nuances of conversation and an eye for descriptive detail that I love. The characters and situations are haunting. My suggestion: have another light book to read afterwards. :)...more

Yet, much of the book is interesting including the medical descriptions of the time (late 1880s) as well as intereting insights on embroidery, fashion,mfabrics, and clothing design. As an immigrant myself, there were passages that struck me as very "true" in their feel. When Irma is offered bread from her homeland, for instance, she has an experience that only those who have been away from the tastes of childhood only to suddenly rediscover them, can feel. I had to go eat a piece of dark heavy rye bread and butter after reading this part! Critical s talk about the author including so many cliches in this novel. title: This and That: The Lost Stories of Emily Carr
author: Carr, Emily
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: While these stories were not all completed to Carr's satisfaction before her death, for anyone who wants to know more about this artistic soul who wasWhile these stories were not all completed to Carr's satisfaction before her death, for anyone who wants to know more about this artistic soul who was not only brilliant, fiercely independent, and talented, but was also one of a handful of modern women artists, these stories are a fabulous find. Emily Carr was one of my favorite painters as an art major in the early 1970s. I even completed a project on her at that time for my amazing professor, the Canadian painter, Gordon A. Smith. Carr was introduced to me by Professor Smoth as a part of the Canadian Group of Seven. She was an acquaintance of Georgia O'Keefe's, and equal to her in vision as well as to Frida Kahlo. Currently Emily Carr's work is on exhibit at Germany's prestigious Documenta art show. While I love her artwork, much of which documents the coastal landscapes and First Nations life in turn of the century British Columbia, Canada, my heart is most attracted to her stories. The Book of Small, Klee Wyck, and many others are gems of storytelling from a very original voice. Ms. Carr won the Governor General's award for Klee Wyck in about 1941. Her books are some of my most cherished reads and I am so thrilled to have rediscovered her work in this latest work as well as in the recent independent film, "Carr, O'Keefe, and Kahlo: Places of their Own."...more

title: Falling to Heaven: The Surprising Path to Happiness
author: Ferrell, James L.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love the paradoxes inherent in the Gospel of Jesus Christ. My sister-in-law gave me a copy of this one. At first I wasn't sure that I "liked" the wrI love the paradoxes inherent in the Gospel of Jesus Christ. My sister-in-law gave me a copy of this one. At first I wasn't sure that I "liked" the writing style and setup but as I went through the chapters and pondered the ideas, I began to see the purpose behind the apparent simplicity of the book. I also wasn't particularly a fan of the stories that he chose to illustrate his points, but the doctrinal insights and scriptures that are cited are thoroughly researched and organized into a cohesive argument. At some points, I feel Ferrell stretches his analogy too far in order to prove his case (he is a lawyer, after all), but this book is a good reminder for our self-absorbed and goal-obsessed Western culture. In the end, until we stop our ceaseless striving to become better than others and realize our nothingness before the perfection of the Savior, we are entirely missing the point of mortality. For only when we begin to see our own imperfections honestly along with our inability to become "light" without the Atonement, do we begin to understand why prophets like Alma, Ammon, Nephi, and Paul, all commented in frustration on their own weakness. We truly must fall down in humility at His feet at our inability to become perfect alone; only then can we be lifted up. It is a hard lesson in our feel-good culture.A favorite quote from G.K. Chesterton:How much larger your life would be if your self could become smaller in it; if you could look at other men with common curiosity and pleasure . . . You would break out of this tiny and tawdry theatre in which your own little plot is always being played, and you would find yourself under a freer sky, and in a street full of splendid strangers....more

Wicked King Leck is dead and his daughter, Bitterblue, is now the young queen. She is faced with unhelpful councilors and ridicoulous mounds of paperwork, but no answers to her questions. At the beginning of the story she is very inexperienced as a ruler. She realizes that she has been kept from the truth concerning the lives of her subjects and the situation in her kingdom since the death of her monster-of-a-father, King Leck. Now,bas she awakens to her responsibilities, she searches for further answers to her past. Her task is to then discover how to awaken her subjects and slowly purge her kingdom of the hidden trauma they have endured. Nice to have Cashore pull in characters from prior novels into this, but I wish we had seen a little more of their personality--especially Katsa and Po--instead of having them appear almost comical in their constant amorous tussling with one another. title: Alone with Others: An Existential Approach to Buddhism
author: Batchelor, Stephen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Years ago I read some of the work of Soren Kierkegaard, an existential Christian writer, whose work fascinated me. Stephen Batchelor also tries in thiYears ago I read some of the work of Soren Kierkegaard, an existential Christian writer, whose work fascinated me. Stephen Batchelor also tries in this book to answer some of the big questions of existence, but through a Buddhist lens. At times, this book is profound, at others I felt it was a bit less finished, but on the whole, this is a very insightful look at what it means to truly be present with yourself as well as with others. The idea of becoming enlightened is really fascinating as it includes self-acceptance and ultimately a turning outward of oneself to truly care for the needs of others. For me, as a Christian, this book reminds me of what we can strive for as humans.Some favorite quotations:Through yoga and meditation I have learned a little about the principle of one-pointed concentration (Samadhi) but Batchelor reminds us with a quote from Tzong Khapa that "one should mount the wisdom which clearly discerns the way things are upon the immovable horse of concentration."On an optimum way of being: ". . . such a person is characterized by three principle qualities. He appears to be possessed of great intuition and wisdom, he radiates deep concern and compassion for others, and he seems to be endowed with an unusual inner strength and will power.""It is only when the optimum mode of being is realized that one achieves the capacity to spontaneously act in such a way that one's every word and deed serves to intimate to others the possibility of experiencing a much fuller and richer existence.""Buddha is nothing but the optimum mode of being possible for man in his present condition."...more

review: I am not one to gush on and on about books, but this one did it for me. The story of Louie Zamperini, former Olympic runner and WWII lieutenant was siI am not one to gush on and on about books, but this one did it for me. The story of Louie Zamperini, former Olympic runner and WWII lieutenant was simply amazing--gut-wrenching, action filled, thoughtful--ultimately one of the best stories of human courage and compassion that I have ever read. Why? As I read, I thought of so many who fought in the World Wars. Like Zamperini, my wonderful father served for five years in the Finnish military, quietly kept an album of photographs, but only briefly alluded to what he had endured. He, like Louie, understood that the brutality and incongruity of war was not something that you could easily define. What fascinated me was the fact that some individuals can endure so much evil and in the end, reach within themselves to find goodness. I recommend this most highly....more

review: This was for our family book group, Nourishing Utterances. It is a harder read for many who don't love history as it has little narrative flow and intThis was for our family book group, Nourishing Utterances. It is a harder read for many who don't love history as it has little narrative flow and introduces so many stories of women that overlap in odd places. I enjoyed parts but felt that although I have lived through these times, I have always been tremendously thrilled to be a woman, rather that feeling oppressed. I do agree with Collins' definition of a feminist--one who is for equal rights under the law and equal wages. Feminism has become a suspect term today, but even in the time of Eliza R. Snow and the early Utah Saints, the LDS women were very involved with the topic of suffrage and equal rights under the law. I am appreciative of women who have paved the way for us today to have opportunities for education, for voting rights, and much more. Today, woman are still treated as chattel in many countries in the world. Even when I grew up, a woman was still paid less than 60% of what a man made for doing the same job. Every woman should at least skim through this book, if only to consider how lucky she is to live in a country that now guarantees so many freedoms. http://nyti.ms/8gCNjE...more

title: The Book Whisperer: Awakening the Inner Reader in Every Child
author: Miller, Donalyn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Loved this book. Donalyn Miller is practical and honest in her recounting of the struggles she had in getting her class to read a book. Then with a liLoved this book. Donalyn Miller is practical and honest in her recounting of the struggles she had in getting her class to read a book. Then with a little "tweak" her students now read dozens of books each year. Her method reminds me of my 6th and 7th grade teacher, Mr. Gibson, a once-in-a-lifetime model of great teaching who somehow came from Glasgow, Scotland to our little provincial Elementary school in White Rock, British Columbia, Canada. Like the author, he allowed us to spend hours reading and discussing literature. We started off reading Nancy Drew and other series books, but slowly were absorbed into more difficult texts that still astonish me. During my years with him, our entire class became readers--Thomas Hardy, Charles Dickens, Jane Austen and the Bronte sisters, were all among the classics which became our friends in a very real way--as we each devoured books under his watchful eye. Frank Smith said that we need to introduce children into the "reading club" by a simple recipe, "the more you read, the better you read; the better you read, the more you read." Worksheets, drills, and boring assessments will never do what reading widely voraciously, and through one's own volition, will. When will grownups wake up to the fact that reading must be caught, not taught? I have always contended that if reading were made a subversive activity, every child in America would be reading at night with a flashlight under their covers. :)I have several friends I have recommended this book to and have heard that their students are reading like never before. ...more

Some chapters are fascinating, and there is plenty to offer a reader who enjoys history: photographs from the LDS Archives and times, as well as chapters about of midwives, healers, schoolmarms, LDS women in fiction, early political suffragettes, plural wives and more. One of my favorite chapters was about Susa Young Gates, the remarkable daughter of Brigham Young. Despite stereotypes to the contrary, the pioneer women of the early Church were accomplished, educated, and often more "liberated" than the women of their day. An insightful and worthwhile work....more

title: Ender’s Game        (Ender's Saga, #1)
author: Card, Orson Scott
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Had this on my bookshelf at the condo and finally decided to read it as it has been an award winner and pivotal work for many subsequent fantasy writeHad this on my bookshelf at the condo and finally decided to read it as it has been an award winner and pivotal work for many subsequent fantasy writers. This is well written, with strongly drawn characters that are sure to live in my personal reading memory. Not being a big reader of sci-fi, I was not particularly excited to read it, but came away thinking about issues such as the military "mind", conditions power, and of course, what it would be like to be a child genius in a society that had few moral guidelines. Interesting to see what has happened in the world of technology since it was written in 1977--now almost 35 years ago!Favorite quote to do with reading:This is the essence of the transaction between storyteller and audience. The "true" story is not one that exists in my mind; it is certainly not the written words on the bound paper you hold in your hands. The story in my mind is nothing but a hope; the text of the story is the tool I created in order to try to make that hope a reality. The story itself, the true story, is the ome that the audience members create in their minds, guided and shaped by my text, but then transformed, elucidated, expanded, edited, and clarified by their own experience, their own desires, their own hopes, and fears....more

title: The Lady of the Lake
author: Scott, Walter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Amazingly, this used to be taught in the 9th grade at the turn of the last century. Don't know if our students could read it today. The story is wondeAmazingly, this used to be taught in the 9th grade at the turn of the last century. Don't know if our students could read it today. The story is wonderful and would make a romantic and action-packed film. At his best, Sir Walter Scott is eloquent and the story flows through it's poetic cantos so quickly that one can't put it down. Some parts however, drag a bit for a modern audience. Based loosely on the reign of James V, King of Scotland, and the beautiful Ellen, this is an almost forgotten yet richly rewarding account of the battles between the Scottish highlanders and lowlanders. With Robin Hood; burning crosses, later sadly adopted by the Klu Klux Klan (the first two words came from the Greek word for circle); the song Hail to the Chief; Schubert's Ave Maria, and much more, the story has a rich cultural footprint.My interest in it was aroused when going through family genealogy and realizing that Duncan as well as Rob Roy are family ancestors. My husband's highland roots come out with every Scottish festival and he reminds me of Sir Douglas in the story--a man of uncommon strength and valor. :) Recommended for those who want to work at reading a little harder as one should at least read the wiki intro first to get a grasp of the three story lines and the major characters. Also, I didn't purchase the book, instead I read the free 1903 Google scan of the Nightingale edition with and introduction by Chalmers. :) It has pages of excellent explanatory notes in the back. Next: Rob Roy by Sir Walter Scott as well!...more

title: Maus I: A Survivor's Tale: My Father Bleeds History        (Maus, #1)
author: Spiegelman, Art
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was one of the first graphic novels to gain popular praise so I thought I'd finally include it on my Goodreads list as it still has so much to reThis was one of the first graphic novels to gain popular praise so I thought I'd finally include it on my Goodreads list as it still has so much to recommend it. The characters are all tied to the Holocaust in one way or another. They are complex and as we see their oft-heated family exchanges, they are "drawn" with a fabulous sense of reality to them. I even recognized something of my own now deceased father in Art's father, also a WWII survivor. Dad would spend hours straightening nails and storing them, and other quaint objects that we who live in such affluence cannot imagine saving. I even remember him being angry about throwing out a crust of bread and saying that one can never know which meal will be your last. He fought on the Russian front for five years. We have no idea what these individuals went through, especially these Jewish people who were caught up in the Holocaust.The graphic novel is intriguing as you examine the subtle shifts of tone in the pictures and the hidden symbols like the naked trees and the road as a swastika when Vladek and Anja Spiegelman, Art's parents, try to find a place of safety in Poland. The story is compelling and the artistry merits study. I have enjoyed considering how the act of reading changes when we "read" the combined text of a comic and a written text. For more on the art of reading comics, check out Scott McCloud's excellent, "Understanding Comics."...more

author: Gruen, Sara*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So the verdict is in. I have to say that the thing I love about a book, is choice, the ability to skip a page when I want. But more on that in a bit. So the verdict is in. I have to say that the thing I love about a book, is choice, the ability to skip a page when I want. But more on that in a bit. I so enjoyed the story of the elder version of the narrator as it really captured some of the indignities and dilemmas of aging in a modern society. What happens when we outlive our usefulness? The character of Jacob in the nursing home as he faded in and out of reality worked well for me and although the ending was a bit far-fetched, it was satisfying. I also enjoyed learning about the circus, and really felt that the author excelled in painting the world surrounding the big top. Prohibition, social norms, boldly drawn characters abounded within the pages of this book.My major issue with the book, however, was the detail of some scenes. Seriously? Does everyone want that much detail about others' sexual proclivities? I wanted to read the story but skipped sections. I love a good romance but miss the days of the camera zooming in for the kiss followed by a fadeout, leaving what followed to one's imagination. ...more

author: Novogratz, Jacqueline*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not always the best writer, if I were judging for literary merit, but her stories are incredibly inspiring and eye-opening as they build a compelling Not always the best writer, if I were judging for literary merit, but her stories are incredibly inspiring and eye-opening as they build a compelling case for how we can help alleviate poverty with innovative solutions. I'm interested in literacy of course, but often that is secondary to meeting basic physical needs. I like the fact that Jacqueline Novograd is a brilliant out-of-the-box thinker. She admits that she has failed at times, but has such commitment to making a difference and through Acumen has finally found ways to make a lasting impact on people, rather than being another do-gooder who gives charity without sustainability. My favorite quotes were many but this stuck with me:"The world will not change with inspiration alone; rather it requires systems, accountability, and clear measures of what works and what doesn't. Our most effective leaders, therefore, will strengthen their knowledge of how to build organizations while also having the vision and the heart to help people imagine that change is possible in their lives." 277This book really opened my eyes to the complexity of making a real difference and how we must be searching for answers to translate what we know into a practical idealism. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The perfect book about timeless values that expose us to our own prejudices and foibles. Simonson is a master of gentle storytelling and the characterThe perfect book about timeless values that expose us to our own prejudices and foibles. Simonson is a master of gentle storytelling and the characters are classic; from stuffy and exacting Major Pettigrew who has never truly been awake to his own life to his luminous foil, the British born Mrs. Ali, who is of Pakistani descent; through his oft-irritating social-climber son, Roger, and the rest of the colorfully drawn villagers of Edgecombe St. Mary, a fictional English village. Laugh-out-loud funny at times, but a perceptive look at what we hold dear. This would be the perfect BBC series. :)See the Washington Post Review: http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/... and the following interview with the author: http://123nonstop.com/watch_online_mo......more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A heart-rending tale, at times wise with humor, about the tragic plight of refugees from countries like Nigeria where petroleum greed and civil unrestA heart-rending tale, at times wise with humor, about the tragic plight of refugees from countries like Nigeria where petroleum greed and civil unrest put entire villages at the mercy of vigilantes. Cleave turns the readers attention to a little known fact of detention centers in supposedly more civilized countries like Great Britain where those who escape the horror of their lives are detained, often for years, in a bureaucratic no-man's land. So well-written and yet, except for Little Bee, I found the characters to be so self-absorbed that they were hard to relate to. But that, perhaps, was the point of the book: how we can be faced with a decision that gives us, no matter how flawed we are, a chance to step up to be counted in something greater than ourselves. The question to ask is, "What am I willing to sacrifice for?" If I am still pondering these things, it was obviously a better book than I thought....more

review: My son-in-law is hiking the Appalachian Trail next year. It will take six months and is over 2,000 miles! He gave me this book to read (I think in hopMy son-in-law is hiking the Appalachian Trail next year. It will take six months and is over 2,000 miles! He gave me this book to read (I think in hopes of persuading my daughter to go with him!) and Bill Bryson, the author, is hilarious. On the other hand, I don't know if Bryson intended to paint such a scary view of the possibilities of hiking one of America's longest trails, but this book, despite it's humorous approach, defines many of the real hazards of hiking through a wilderness. Bryson has a way of making stories out of the most simple situations. author: Cao, Lan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Having grown up with the Vietnam War, I really have been surprised by how little we were told about the culture and the displacement that occured withHaving grown up with the Vietnam War, I really have been surprised by how little we were told about the culture and the displacement that occured with the split of the country into two. As a Canadian at the time, I heard of peace protests and encountered draft dogers in Vancouver while I went to university. Photos in the media captured a little of the agony and suffering of the Vietnamese people as well as the confusion, loss, and anger of GIs who returned, not as heros, but as a lost generation. The war became synonomous with a national fiasco, it seemed. The Americans wanted out and and the faithful soldiers with PTS who couldn't reintegrate became an embarassment to the government. This book was recommended at NCTE this past fall.Just finished it and have to say that it has been, surprisingly, one of the most moving books that I have read for quite some time. Th relationship between Mai and her mother is extraordinarily drawn, a stifled whisper, where there should have been much more. How odd our relationships can be, and to what lengths mothers go to protect their children. Succulent images of the beauty that was Viet Nam as well as the terror that is war. Not for every reader, but with this who are interested in the history of the era and family memoir, this one will linger....more

review: Vern Swanson has a Ph.D. and is the curator of the Springville Museum of Art. He presented some of this material at a BYU symposium several years ago Vern Swanson has a Ph.D. and is the curator of the Springville Museum of Art. He presented some of this material at a BYU symposium several years ago but this book is the result of decades of pondering about the revelations, histories, and legends, that surround the birth and lineage of Jesus and Christ. As Swanson states at the end of the book, this is a hefty "tome" with a great deal of piecing together of what "could have happened." Many of the thoughts that he proposes debunk more popular approaches such as the "Da Vinci Code" and help shed a lot of light and offer much food for thought. I know that this book will prove controversial for some, but like another of my favorites, Rough Stone Rolling," it is recommended for those who enjoy thinking and putting pieces of the proverbial puzzle together....more

title: Nefertiti
author: Author Moran, Michelle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kirstie recommended this as a fun summer read, knowing I enjoy historical fiction. Even on the Kindle, I couldn't put it down. The life of the EgyptiaKirstie recommended this as a fun summer read, knowing I enjoy historical fiction. Even on the Kindle, I couldn't put it down. The life of the Egyptian Queen Nefertiti, considered the most beautiful woman in the world, has always intrigued me and Moran had done enough homework in order to imaginatively fill in the copious gaps in what we know about this political era. Some ers have objected to the portrayal of Nefertiti, but, hey, this is historical fiction and an author can take liberties with characterization within this genre. I remember reading Jean Plaidy's novels about the British royals as a teen and thinking that the thing that historical fiction does best is makes one curious about history. So, as we have no way to substantiate if the details are "true" the story told through her sister's eyes was delightful, filled with action, romance, intrigue, and enough history to make it an enjoyable and fast summer read....more

title: Temple Theology: An Introduction
author: Barker, Margaret
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Mormons build temples. So did the early peoples of New Testament times. So why don't other modern Christians or Jews? What did happen to temple worshiMormons build temples. So did the early peoples of New Testament times. So why don't other modern Christians or Jews? What did happen to temple worship between the first temple period (Solomon) and the second to have Christ call it corrupt? How does the Mosaic Law figure in? Who was Melchizedek? Margaret Barker is an amazing scholar and unconventional thinker. She goes into places where many scripture experts fear to tread and does original research from primary documents that keep being unearthed in the Middle East. Even if you don't agree with her conclusions on the split between the Deuteronomists and the earlier covenant people such as Abraham (known to Jews and Arabs as the father of the covenant), there is so much to think about in her writing. I know that I will take this one off the shelf to ponder many times. For more on Barker, go to her website: http://www.margaretbarker.com/ Also hear her interviewed by the Backyard Professor on YouTube :)...more

review: Like Kogawa's "Obasan" and Uchida's "Journey to Topaz" this piece of historical fiction discusses the plight of North Americans, who also happened to Like Kogawa's "Obasan" and Uchida's "Journey to Topaz" this piece of historical fiction discusses the plight of North Americans, who also happened to be Japanese, during WWII. The story takes place in Seattle and centers around a young Chinese American boy, Henry, who attends an all white school on "scholarship." He works in the school lunchroom to pay for part of his tuition and is treated with disdain by his schoolmates. His life changes as does his view of the world when Keiko, a Japanese American girl becomes his best friend. The story explores their relationship through a forty year time period, including her family's internment at the Washington State Fairground in Puyallup and then at Camp Harmony in Minidoka, Idaho. Jazz, art, cultural clashes, and love gently fill out this satisfying first novel....more

title: The Brain That Changes Itself: Stories of Personal Triumph from the Frontiers of Brain Science
author: Doidge, Norman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've always suspected that the brain is malleable; that would stand to reason knowing our eternal nature and due to the fact that it is rumored that aI've always suspected that the brain is malleable; that would stand to reason knowing our eternal nature and due to the fact that it is rumored that at best, we only use 4% of it. Who wouldn't be interested in building themselves a better brain? This books explains many aspects of modern neuroscience, arguing for plasticity, while much of our scientific community is still stuck in Decartean thinking where the brain is "hardwired" with fixed regions that limit human intelligence, growth, healing, and change. In a culture where everyone is bent on a "quick fix" through surgery or drugs and trusts a medical establishment that is too often immersed in neurological nihilism, it is an exceptionally brave endeavor to go against the status quo and write a book such as this. I am not convinced that all of his quoted scientific research is exceptional, but he makes a very compelling case.Malleability or plasticity as Doidge calls it, is found in four areas:1. Brain map expansion2. Sensory reassignment3. Compensatory masquerade4. Mirror region takeoverAll of these kinds of plasticity are discussed in detail in the book and have been identified by Jordan Grafman, the chief of the Congnitive Neursciences section, National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NIH). My favorite sections include Merzenich's research on dyslexia and other forms of language impairment among children (pp 69-83); the extended mental lifespan section (pp.84-91) that even talks about why we need to walk barefoot as often as possible when we age; a section on imagination and its effects on mental practice including the inhibition of pain (pp. 199-204; a chapter on neurogenesis (Ch 10); and how children caught between two cultures can modify their brains (298-304). Yes, we can become sharper, faster, and more brilliant with age!Favorite quote: "When Pablo Casals, the cellist, was ninety-one years old, he was approached by a student who asked, "Master, why do you continue to practice?" Casals replied, "Because I am making progress." (257)...more

title: Light in the Wilderness: Explorations in the Spiritual Life
author: Thomas, M. Catherine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I recall the day when pouring yet again through 2 Nephi when I realized that the wilderness mentioned in the story was really but a type and shadow ofI recall the day when pouring yet again through 2 Nephi when I realized that the wilderness mentioned in the story was really but a type and shadow of our life journey. After years of putting pieces together, I am so grateful to find a book, so packed with ideas that expand upon those I have recorded in my own journey as a spiritual seeker. As Truman Madsen wrote, "this remarkable and penetrating book deals with some of the toughest spiritual issues of our time." I just wish I had discovered it earlier. This book will be received as unconventional by some, but Thomas, a retired professor of Ancient Scripture at BYU has written a masterpiece on the spiritual journey. See Richard Cracroft's  in BYU Magazine: http://magazine.byu.edu/?act=view&... "To explore the challenging route to spiritual reality Thomas draws freshly and deeply on scripture and on the sermons of Joseph Smith, Brigham Young, Orson Pratt, Parley P. Pratt, Charles W. Penrose, F. Enzio Busche, and Hugh Nibley, among others. She opens to readers the experiences of such various light seekers and bearers as Jacques Lusseyran, Deepak Chopra, Sakyong Mipham, and Cardinal John Henry Newman and shares the poetry of John Milton, William Wordsworth, and William Blake. For, as Joseph Smith insisted, “one of the grand fundamental principles of Mormonism is to receive truth—let it come from where it may” (quoted in Thomas, p. xi)."...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In the end, science is finally corroborating the fact that love for oneself and for others, as well as forgiveness and letting go create health. TrumaIn the end, science is finally corroborating the fact that love for oneself and for others, as well as forgiveness and letting go create health. Truman's book is in its 13th printing--a classic in the field of awareness of how physical health and mental/emotional patterns that we hold interrelate. Not particularly well written, but chapter 4 is a good overview of Truman's thinking, and the the tables in chapter 17 on types of feelings and chapter 18 on the causes of illness are food for thought (see also Louise Hays' version called "You Can Heal Your Life"). If nothing else, this book allows people to begin to think about how they may blaming everything in their lives on circumstances outside of themselves (family situations, parents, genetics, job, etc.), and realize how important it is to take responsibility for their own health and well-being. Physical, mental, and emotional pain should not be "stuffed" down; if we want to enjoy life, the journey must start with accepting responsibility for ourselves. ...more

This was one of my father's favorite's of his collected works--he translated this into Finnish in 1990. review: My colleague Gary Hatch ed this book before he passed away a couple of years ago. Here are his remarks. They are worth reading:"When David McCulMy colleague Gary Hatch ed this book before he passed away a couple of years ago. Here are his remarks. They are worth reading:"When David McCullough visited BYU, he made the somewhat obvious but significant point that history didn't have to turn out the way it did. This is one of the major themes of this book. If the wind had shifted direction at the wrong time during the Battle of Long Island, or if the fog hadn't settled in during Washington's retreat across the East River, then the Revolution might have ended then and there. But it wasn't just Providence that made the difference, it also was the courage and character of individual soldiers that turned the tide, Washington himself being a key figure. McCullough quotes George Otto Trevelyan, who wrote, "It may be doubted whether so small a number of men ever employed so short a space of time with greater and more lasting effects upon the history of the world." That the Continental Army survived the year 1776 at all is miraculous. McCullough writes with clarity and energy and has done a remarkable job synthesizing a vast amount of scholarship."Miss your insights, Gary. ...more

review: Ambitious, beautiful writing and engaging use of voice in this novel. While I agree with many of the very positive s and felt as if Kingsolver'sAmbitious, beautiful writing and engaging use of voice in this novel. While I agree with many of the very positive s and felt as if Kingsolver's reading of historical events in the Congo was enlightening, I felt that my chief disappointment was the underdevelopment of the father as a character. He was so flat; a caricature . Kingsolver painted him with broad brushstrokes into an abusive, tyrannical fanatic, who in short lacked any redeeming qualities. I understand that some individuals are wounded or broken, but people are generally more complex than the father. Why would Leah be so dogged on her early determination to follow him? Perhaps this was a character with progressive mental illness? I'd love to hear a psychologist's read of this book. Also, for me, Rachel's voice seems to come from an inauthentic place--not that individuals like her do not exist, but her voice didn't ring true to me as a reader and I cannot pinpoint why. ...more

title: Half the Sky: Turning Oppression into Opportunity for Women Worldwide
author: Kristof, Nicholas D.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So far (I am half-way through) this has to be a wake-up call for every intelligent human being on the planet. Incredible stories that are so painful tSo far (I am half-way through) this has to be a wake-up call for every intelligent human being on the planet. Incredible stories that are so painful to read about. Am trying to decide what to do to help--have an educational project with Africa I am involved with that might be the answer. Read Chapter 6, for instance, and you will weep at the incredible state of a world who pays for wars but ignores human dignity.Finally finished. The challenge of this book is to face up to the humanitarian concerns of women locked up in brothels, sold into slavery, left dying in huts because of no access to fistula surgery, women who are beaten, raped and demeaned because of cultural ignorance and tradition. Because of who we are, and the tremendous opportunities we have been given in this "promised land," we cannot read about these injustices, sigh, and go on with our comfortable lives. We have to find ways to be involved in ending suffering and ignorance in our communities and throughout the world. The authors offer many concrete options at the end of the book--ways in which each reader can make a small difference. While I do not necessarily agree with all of the author's conclusions from the data that they present, I feel that this is one of the most important books of the past decade. As Brigham Young, the LDS prophet and visionary leader stated over 150 years ago, "If I had a choice of educating my daughters or my sons because of opportunity constraints, I would choose to educate my daughters." This is not a sexist statement, but a necessity in most parts of the world; especially when one takes a more broad look at what the term education can imply. Women in a society must realize their worth and dignity and be valued by men, in order for a society to evolve. As Greg Mortenson writes in "Three Cups of Tea," the "enemy is ignorance." He has concluded after years of working with villagers in remote reaches of Afghanistan and Pakistan that "Once you educate the boys, they tend to leave the villages and go search for work in the cities . . . but girls stay home, become leaders in the community, and pass on what they've learned. If you really want to change a culture . . . the answer is to educate girls."...more

review: Delightful. Based on historical circumstances, Schmidt, an English professor, sets this award-winning story of friendship and coming-of-age on the MaiDelightful. Based on historical circumstances, Schmidt, an English professor, sets this award-winning story of friendship and coming-of-age on the Maine coastline in Phippsburg, a town near Malaga Island. The time period is about 1905, when the publication of Charles Darwin's "Origin of the Species" shocked a nation from their slumber. Rich with descriptions of the coastline and the Atlantic shore, the book is evocative without overly long passages. I emerged, having climbed with Turner on the granite outcroppings, smelling the pines and rainstorms. Turner is the son of a very conservative preacher, the third Buckminster (III), and cannot seem to do anything right in the eyes of other boys his age, his parents, and of course, the townsfolk. The appearance of Lizzy, a resident of Malaga, sets the historical events of the story in motion. A favorite reading quote:Reverend Buckminster on deciding whether to allow Turner to read Darwin: "Turner," he said, "books can be fire you know.""Fire?""Fire. Books can ignite fires in your mind, because they carry ideas for kindling, and art for matches." He handed the book to Turner. (129)...more

title: Eve and the Choice Made in Eden
author: Campbell, Beverly
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had, years ago, read Beverly Campbells' excellent article on this subject (given April 2, 1993, at the 11th annual conference of Collegium AesculapiI had, years ago, read Beverly Campbells' excellent article on this subject (given April 2, 1993, at the 11th annual conference of Collegium Aesculapium in Salt Lake City, Utah). Campbell was then director of International Affairs for The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Campbell, also a director of the Joseph P. Kennedy Foundation and a founder of the Special Olympics program here, in a more watered down version, shares some insights on the story of Eden. Who was Eve? As a young Lutheran girl, I was always a little embarrassed to have been descended from Eve as Adam seemed so wise and righteous. The world portrays Eve as somehow a failure: weak, easily deceived, and mentally incapable of making a good decision. As a member of the LDS church I have come to realize that Eve was truly glorious and beautiful, a perfect woman as a match for Adam. In an early vision that opens to Zebedee Coltrin, Joseph Smith and Oliver Cowdery, they see "two most beautiful and perfect specimens of mankind [they had:] ever [seen:]." Zebedee writes that "Joseph said, They are our first parents,' Adam and Eve." He continues that "Adam was a large broad-shouldered man, and Eve, as a woman, was as large in proportion." B. H. Roberts, "New Witnesses for God, 2:7.If one believes that the purpose of mortality is to progress to become more Christlike in all of our attributes, we are able to do this through a conscious decision-making process called agency. We come to earth from a pre-existent state in order to learn to choose wisely and grow to become more like our Father--Eloheim, the Eternal God. The Fall was a necessary part of an eternal plan. Eve's choice was to transgress one law in order to fulfill another law, the commandment to "multiply and replenish the earth." Our placement on earth stems from the agency that Eve exercises on behalf of all mankind, a transgression from the garden state to mortality, without which the entire plan of God would have no meaning and Adam and Eve would still be wandering around in Eden alone. So how was Eve able to make this choice? Was it because she was simple and confused or was it a carefully thought out decision? I concur with Campbell that it was the latter.As brain research is beginning to indicate, perhaps men and women think differently. Men seem to think in terms of absolute justice (black and white, right and wrong), whereas women's thinking is generally more intuitive and multidimensional. Women's brains are hardwired to think in terms of "highest best good" and interrelationships (the qualities of mercy) or what Beverly Campbell calls a "morality of responsibility. " In fact, research on how morality develops within societies indicates that morality scales are based on studies which do not include women as subjects! See Alma 42:24 for an interesting insight on the terms his and hers.In the Genesis (and Moses) account, Adam is given a commandment to not partake of the tree of knowledge of good and evil in a time before Eve is created (Genesis 2:16-17). He, as a black and white thinker will not break the commandment of God by his own volition. Eve, on the other hand, uses the type of thinking that allows for a morality of responsibility and realizes that without transgressing one law, she breaks another (multiple and replenish the earth) and cannot ever bear children to fulfill God's other commandment. How long she ponders this choice is not told to us, but over time, she comes to the decision that if Adam will not do it, she must. And what a gift she gives us. Through her brave and well-reasoned choice, we learn that mortality is a probationary period in which we are allowed to choose and to know by our own experience "the good from the evil." Adam and Eve, for me, epitomize the best of a marriage relationship and partnership as they complement each others ways of being and even each others' thought processes. 1 Corinthians 11:11 talks of this. Who'd have guessed? It looks as if God knew all along why man and women were intended to become of one heart and one mind. :) Also read: Alonzo Gaskill's book on the subject, The Savior and the Serpent: Unlocking The Doctrine of the Fall....more

review: Some of my favorite readers loved this book and as I think I "stole" it from Holly at Christmas, I couldn't wait to try it out. Very enjoyable. UnlikeSome of my favorite readers loved this book and as I think I "stole" it from Holly at Christmas, I couldn't wait to try it out. Very enjoyable. Unlike Meg, who lives for the dramas of the inner life, I actually like trudging through the physical wilderness under insurmountable odds :) Katsa has no self-awareness or self-discipline at the beginning of the tale, and I felt as if I was reliving "self-centered teenagers that I have known," including myself, but as she begins to see herself through her experiences with others, she slowly awakens and becomes conscious of her inner world and how her choices affect others. Cashore presents an often funny, innovative view of human gifts and talents and what we may choose to do with them as well as a great psychological analysis of a character's growth. Kudos. My only hesitation is due to the relationship that Katsa develops. If YA is an opportunity for young adults to vicariously experience rich relationships, I was disappointed that Cashore takes the easy way out to allow Katsa freedom without the obligations and discipline required in a marriage. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have to admit that my tastes are not what they were in my teens and twenties. I loved the flawed characters in this well-crafted tale. Maugham is a I have to admit that my tastes are not what they were in my teens and twenties. I loved the flawed characters in this well-crafted tale. Maugham is a wonderful writer with an eye for detail and nuance. He leaves the reader with so many unanswered questions in this book, which make it a joy to read. Kitty Fane (rhymes with vane -- like The Vane Sisters--Nabokov's tale is delightful, by the way), is vacuous and undisciplined at the book's beginning. By the end, will she have learned anything? There are no neat endings and "the way" through this book is as complex as the veil that has been drawn over life itself. Certainly at the end one can reread and find foreshadowing and writerly glimpses and gestures, but this is a sophisticated read about a developing personality, not a romance. This book offers insights into so many windows including the sometimes absurdities of love, the nature of spirituality, the disasters of upbringing, the foibles of self-importance and left me wanting to return to Maugham and discover more of his craft. Favorite line: Siena mi fe; disfecemi Maremma. ...more

title: Galileo's Daughter: A Historical Memoir of Science, Faith and Love
author: Sobel, Dava
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Renaissance truly was an awakening for much of Western European thought. In 1564 Galileo Galilei is born in Pisa on February 15. Michelangelo BuonThe Renaissance truly was an awakening for much of Western European thought. In 1564 Galileo Galilei is born in Pisa on February 15. Michelangelo Buonarroti dies in Florence, February 18. (William Shakespeare is born in England, April 23). Filled with novel detail including the fact that Viviani, the beloved student of Galileo’s old age “promulgated the belief that Michelangelo’s spirit had leaped like an inspiration from his aged, failing body to the infant Galileo in the brief span of hours separating the former’s death from the latter’s birth” is sometimes simply stunning to contemplate. The biography, which took me about two years to finish (I tend to be a slow and careful reader of this type of writing) is generally fascinating, but will not be everyone’s choice as it strays into so many areas in its subject matter: from the day-to-day minutiae of a Poor Clare nun’s life (the letters of Seur Celeste, Galileo’s daughter) and her thoughts on how many scudis a bottle of wine will bring or what natural medicines might repel the bubonic plague, through European and Italian City State politics, circling around intriguing religious squabbles and Galileo’s trial at the Vatican, and naturally ing, often in great and often illustrated detail, the theoretical and scientific thinking of this genius. If you have ever laid on the grass on a summer’s evening gazing up at the stars or wondered at the changing tides or pondered why the face in the moon never changes even as the moon revolves around the earth, this book will both educate and delight you.Some interesting quotations:“Galileo would engage this same cosmic conflict with the Church, treading a dangerous path between the Heaven he revered as a good Catholic and the heavens he revealed through his telescope.”A ... “duration of forty days—quaranta giorni in Italian, from which the word quarantine” is derived.“Fully 50 percent of the daughters of Florentine patrician families spent at least part of their lives within convent walls.”Lastly, rhe delightful and creative writing of Sister Celeste: “In this last post your letters arrived like the Franciscan friars wearing their wooden clogs, not only yoked together, but with a resounding clatter, creating in me a much greater than usual commotion of pleasure and happiness . . .”...more

review: Elder Jeffrey R. Holland is a marvelous writer. This took me well over a year to read, as it is meant to be pondered or as Sir Francis Bacon said, "diElder Jeffrey R. Holland is a marvelous writer. This took me well over a year to read, as it is meant to be pondered or as Sir Francis Bacon said, "digested," and is one of the classics that I will reach for over and over. It is a masterpiece in its comprehension of key doctrines of the Book of Mormon and how they point to Jesus Christ and the New Covenant. Some of my favorite chapters were on types and shadows and the Law of Moses, the relationship between the Father and the Son, Moroni's elucidation of faith, hope and charity, and of course, the chapters on Christ's visit to the Americas. As I finished reading this I can only echo Elder Holland's words:In a lifetime of reading, the Book of Mormon stands preeminent in my intellectual and spiritual life, the classic of all classics, a reaffirmation of the Holy Bible, a voice from the dust, a witness for Christ, the word of the Lord unto Salvation....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a very unusual book, published in England in 1969, about what the next world is like. A colleague dropped it off at my office and said it has This is a very unusual book, published in England in 1969, about what the next world is like. A colleague dropped it off at my office and said it has some fascinating insights. I don't know what to say about it being "gospel truth" but do know that some of the things that the late Francis Banks describes through Helen Greaves seem to make such sense. Read D&C 76, 88, 138 and compare. A lot of fascinating concepts to think about that appear to corroborate why near death experiencers from all ethnic backgrounds talk of the light, love and peace that they felt on the other side of the veil and at the same time speak of seeing things that seem to fit their frame of earthly understanding (i.e., their religious beliefs, what heaven" is like, and more). It appears that after death we find ourselves in a place where we are slowly healed of our earthly misconceptions and taught according to our desires to understand and no faster. Banks talks of being clothed in garments of light, of the absence of time as we understand it, of the service that we are engaged in as we teach others, of temples of learning, of the possibility of eternal progression, and so much more. Food for thought....more

review: A few really excellent chapters on temples throughout history. Interesting to read about the similarities between cultures and how temples sprang up iA few really excellent chapters on temples throughout history. Interesting to read about the similarities between cultures and how temples sprang up in areas as diverse and geographically distanced as Egypt, Israel, Assyria, India, Cambodia, and China. Temples are set apart and often centered on a "primal hillock" as sacred spaces and introduce the sacred or holy into institutionalized relationships. James Livingston's book, "Anatomy of the Sacred: An Introduction to Religion" is an excellent study of why we as humans desire ritual in our lives for its social and psychological functions; even "rituals" as simple as celebrating holidays with friends and family, or at bare minimum, how we nestle down to read the morning paper or check our email :) ...more

title: The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian
author: Alexie, Sherman
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay. I loved this book. It is very frank, deals with tough subjects, has loads of teenage hormonal boy sexual references, but is also so real and smaOkay. I loved this book. It is very frank, deals with tough subjects, has loads of teenage hormonal boy sexual references, but is also so real and smart and thoughtful. All the characters seem to have a life of their own, including Grandmother Spirit. Junior, a Spokane Indian, decides to leave the "rez" and attend a white school. You laugh and cry with Junior as he learns to believe that he can succeed, even with overwhelming odds. While having grown up with Native American friends (in Canada they call themselves, "First People", I can't pretend to understand the culture that they come from, but have seen alcoholism, teen pregnancy, despair, and much more consume many of their best and brightest. My friend Gloria George's grandfather, Chief Dan George, wrote the following article that was published in the 1972 LDS Ensign, entitled, My People, the Indians" that might help you understand the world of Sherman Alexie better: https://www.lds.org/ensign/1972/08/my... . I have used this article for many years with my own students.For those of you who choose not to share this book with high school students, I am sorry. I understand that you want a perfect world. But, it is not. It is often, ugly, cruel, and unfair. But frankly, what we did in the name of the Constitution to the Native Americans in order to expand our nation was ugly, cruel, and unfair. How can we ever open the eyes of our students to the plight of others if we shelter them too much? How can we, as the First People say, walk in another man's moccasin's if we turn our back and pretend they are not as human or righteous or privileged as we?...more

title: Science and the Akashic Field: An Integral Theory of Everything
author: Laszlo, Ervin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Lazlo is simply brilliant. That said, this is a brave book for an established systems theory genious to write. It takes empirical research to an uncomLazlo is simply brilliant. That said, this is a brave book for an established systems theory genious to write. It takes empirical research to an uncomfortable place for most A-B "rational" Descartian thinkers. Gasp--it even verges on reaching for answers to those terrible questions that tippy-toe about the sublime. "Who are we? Where did we come from? Is there something after this pale existence?" The author (whose writing could have been more effective in the latter chapters with a little less "fluff") employs systems theory to integrate the specialized knowledge found in diverse disciplines such as astrophysics, quantum physics, molecular biology, and even consciousness studies into a holistic interdisciplinary model that frankly is so elegant that it takes one's breath away. His basic premise is a philosophic one, built upon the life works of brilliant scholars in each of these fields. Called the quantum/vacuum interaction hypothesis or A-field (the hypothesized fifth field after gravity, electromagnetic, strong and weak force), his theory (for I call it such) takes what Carl Jung calls the collective unconscious or what eastern philosophers have postulated for millenia: we live in a universe built upon coherence, continuity, and consciousness. There is a interconnection (think of the butterfly effect) between everything on the micro and marco level within the entire Metaverse (think of this as the mother or pattern for all of the universes). In fact, he postulates, the metaverse contains an encoding or patterning that creates new universes that come into being with the same possibility of evolutionary life and agency that we experience here on our own planet. There is much more to digest here. Very worthwhile reading.Favorite quotes: "the memory of the universe may be eternal." "In the final count, the evolutionist/creationist controversy has no point. The question "Design or evolution?" poses a false alternative. Design and evolution do not exclude each other; indeed they require one another. The Metaverse is unlikely to have come into existence out of nothing, as a result of pure chance. And if it was designed, it was evidently so designed that it could evolve. The truth of the matter is not "design or evolution." It is design for evolution." 128...more

title: Eat, Pray, Love
author: Gilbert, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I understand why everyone would not enjoy this book and after I read the general postings either complaining or agreeing its merits (apparently it is I understand why everyone would not enjoy this book and after I read the general postings either complaining or agreeing its merits (apparently it is on the Oprah list), I have to agree with Jon Kabat-Zinn that everyone is wrapped up in ego-projections--which they accused the author of being. We really care most about ourselves and how we feel about everything, whether we want to admit it or not. I have met very few self-actualized individuals in my life and definitely fewer enlightened ones. Eat, Pray, Love was certainly not great literature, and written unevenly in places, but it was also at times funny, poignant, heart-rending, earthy, and informative. Sadly, people felt betrayed by the final section--accusing the narrator of giving up her search for God in the process of rediscovering love. Hey. . . that's life. We are either happy and fulfilled or we are not. If finding love gets us closer to God, or towards the feeling of happiness, what is wrong with that? Not everyone needs to spend the rest of their days in an ashram. After all, it is easy to be mindful and peaceful when away from "real life" but the ability to live among others, especially those who we automatically don't love is the thing that really tests our compassion and ability to be mindful.Anyway, this was not a book about finding God as much as about first finding oneself and then having an ability to look at that individual in the mirror with forgiveness, humor, and compassion. As Gilbert wisely writes:This is what we are like. Collectively, as a species, this is our emotional landscape. I met an old lady once, almost one hundred years old, and she told me, "There are only two questions that human beings have ever fought over all though history. How much do you love me? And Who's in charge?" . . . But these two questions of love and control undo us all, trip us up and cause war, grief and suffering." 157...more

title: A Thousand Splendid Suns
author: Hosseini, Khaled*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really didn't read this wishing to be endlessly entertained (having read the s and spoilers), but rather, hoping that I would learn more aboutI really didn't read this wishing to be endlessly entertained (having read the s and spoilers), but rather, hoping that I would learn more about this volatile area of the world and what I, personally might be able to do to help out. After reading Mortenson's Three Cups of Tea, I wonder again at the international community and the blind eye most of us turn towards those who are in need. Are we not our brother's and sister's keepers? Although I was at Sundance a few years ago queued up to see the film premiere, "The Giant Buddha's" mentioned in this novel, I am startled that they made such headlines in the US news compared to the untold misery that individuals in these warring countries have endured. And why should we care? Because we have been given so much and so few of us are actively engaged in giving back. I suppose I am asking that you do something more than read to be entertained--although we cannot do everything, we can take the time to find a cause or charity that makes a difference for others. My personal cause is literacy and I advocate for the International Reading Associate which works with agencies internationally to make a difference in the lives of children by teaching them to read. I also am very interested in literacy for women, particularly in third world countries, agreeing with Mortenson who state that if you educate a woman, you educate a village. Ken Mortensen speaks for many of us who want to make a difference: "Fighting terror is may be seventh or eighth on my list of priorities. But working over there, I’ve learned a few things. I’ve learned that terror doesn’t happen beacause some group of people somewhere like Pakistan or Afghanistan simply decide to hate us. It happens because children aren’t being offered a bright enough future that they have a reason to choose life over death."I am naive enough to believe that schools and universal literacy are the cure for terrorism. ...more

title: Things Fall Apart        (The African Trilogy, #1)
author: Achebe, Chinua
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book and my reaction to it was intense. I know better than to expect a main character to be likable, and I want to like him, but Okonkwo is flaweThis book and my reaction to it was intense. I know better than to expect a main character to be likable, and I want to like him, but Okonkwo is flawed--how can you love a man who is determined to be so blind to human kindness that he beats his wives and children and superstitiously refuses to take a stand against the murder of innocents because he has such a hatred towards his own father's soft nature? But I protest with little effect on history. For I am reading from a viewpoint so distanced from the African culture that Chinua Achebe describes, and from a personal "moral" compass and upbringing that is so different. My mind wanders to my horror at waterboarding. His is a culture that honors warriors. It reminds me of reading Sophocles' Oedipus, which I taught several years ago in a senior class along with books such as Anne Michael's "Fugitive Pieces," and, of course, Max Frish's "Homo Faber." The theme of the course was on human blindness. This would have fit perfectly. Okonkwo is a tragic protagonist, but I cannot say hero, for even in his tribe, he was often corrected by his elders for his lack of restraint. In the background of his story, we see the equally blind white incursion upon his culture and the destruction of much of what has held his culture together. This is powerful reading that infuriates you and at the same time, sweeps you inexorably along to its tragic conclusion. An excellent book to discuss in a high school classroom....more

review: While I wandered around in Abiquiu and on the grounds of Ghost Ranch, this volume of poems, written in the 1970s by Carol, her weekend secretary, librWhile I wandered around in Abiquiu and on the grounds of Ghost Ranch, this volume of poems, written in the 1970s by Carol, her weekend secretary, librarian, cook, and companion, opened windows into O'Keeffe's world. Carol's poetic interactions with O'Keeffe's world and view become more sophisticated and pure through the pages as she learns how to "see" from O'Keeffe. While these anecdotes stand alone as poetry, together they give a valuable historical account of some of O'Keeffe's final years (she died in 1986 in Santa Fe). Ironically, as Merrill learns to see, Georgia faces the loss of her own eyesight to macular degeneration.A must read for O'Keeffe scholars and those who want to know more about the life of this important American artist....more

review: When we moved to Mississippi someone recommended that I read this book (1992) as I really told a story of the South that needs to be understood. AfterWhen we moved to Mississippi someone recommended that I read this book (1992) as I really told a story of the South that needs to be understood. After the first gruesome chapter, I didn't think that I would be able to go on as I am not a fan of violence, but luckily a colleague at the University of Mississippi encouraged me to read on. The plotline gripped me and I became a closet fan of Grisham's, although I have to say that none of his subsequent books have matched up to one. ...more
